summary: In CSP2, the `'self'` source expression explicitly excludes `blob:` and `filesystem:`. This means that developers will need to add those schemes explicitly to their directives if they wish to include content at those URLs.

name: CSP3: The 'strict-dynamic' source expression.

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The 'strict-dynamic' source expression allows script loaded via nonce- or hash-based whitelists to load other script, simplifying the requirements for deployment, and (hopefully!) making it more likely that CSP can reach more sites.

name: CSP3: The 'worker-src' directive

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The 'worker-src' directive restricts the URLs which may be loaded as a Worker, SharedWorker, or ServiceWorker. It falls back to 'child-src' (which, in turn, falls back to 'default-src').

name: CSP3: unsafe-hashes

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
'unsafe-hashes' is a feature in CSP3 which allows developers to enable specific event handlers without needing to use the less safe 'unsafe-inline' keyword.
If 'unsafe-hashes' is present, inline event handlers are allowed to match against hashes specified by the 'script-src' directive (or its fallback if not present).

name: CSP: Embedded Enforcement

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: CSP's Embedded enforcement  defines a mechanism by which a web page can embed a nested browsing context if and only if it agrees to enforce a particular set of restrictions upon itself. We should prototype an implementation to see if it's something that solves real problems in a way we can ship.

name: CSP: Insecure source expressions match secure URLs.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: In the wake of Sniffly, it seems pretty reasonable to prevent folks from locking themselves into insecurity. To that end, Insecure schemes in source expressions now match their secure variants. That is, `http:` is equivalent to `http: https:`, and `http://a.com` to `http://a.com https://a.com`.

name: CSP: SecurityPolicyViolationEvent for Workers.

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: When a Worker's CSP is violated, we should fire a 'SecurityPolicyViolation' event at its global object.

name: CSP: `report-sample` property in violation reports

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The `report-sample` property attempts to reach consensus on an opt-in variant Firefox's behavior. In short, we'll collect a 40-character sample for inline script and style violations, and include it in the violation report (and associated SecurityPolicyViolationEvent object) iff a 'report-sample' expression is present in the violated directive.

name: CSP: `report-to` directive

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The `report-to` directive wires CSP violation reports up to the Reporting API which allows the browser to bundle multiple reports when sending them to the server rather than creating a POST for each individual report. This allows reports to be collected in a way that is friendlier for users' batteries. This change also deprecates the existing `report-uri` directive.

view.notes:
The SEAM Google team has plans for using this feature for a static page automatic CSP system.



Also interest has been expressed for a method of only enabling "style" attributes to prevent CSS based attacks (as the one linked above).

name: CSP: `script-src-attr`, `script-src-elem`, `style-src-attr`, `style-src-elem` directives

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: These 4 new directives provide the functionality of the script/style directive but with more granularity, applying to elements or attributes.

name: CSS "all" shorthand

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The all property is a shorthand that resets all CSS properties except direction and unicode-bidi. It only accepts the CSS-wide keywords.

name: CSS 'ic' Length Unit

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Support for expressing CSS lengths relative to the used advance measure of the CJK water ideograph.

view.notes: Implemented behind a flag

name: CSS 'lh' Length Unit

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The 'lh' unit adds support for expressing CSS lengths relative to the line-height.

That is typically useful for specifying the height of an element to fit a whole number of lines. Example: textarea { height: 5lh }

name: CSS 'q' length unit

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
support 'q' absolute length unit.
1q is equivalent to 1/40th of 1cm.

name: CSS -webkit-user-modify

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
-webkit-user-modify is a non-standard CSS property inherited from WebKit. It was introduced to define editability on elements. 

Now we have a better alternative: the HTML5 contenteditable attribute. -webkit-user-modify should leave the stage.

name: CSS -webkit-user-select: all

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The user-select property enables authors to specify which elements in the document can be selected by the user and how.
Chrome has supported only prefixed version: -webkit-user-select.

With -webkit-user-select:all value,
the content of the element must be selected atomically: If a selection would contain part of the element, then the selection must contain the entire element including all its descendants.

view.notes:
However, it doesn't support 'content', 'direction', 'unicode-bidi' nor some font properties.
And it can't follow a ::slotted() selector despite being tree-abiding.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4572353/do-any-browsers-support-the-css3-pseudo-element-marker

name: CSS ::marker pseudo-element

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The ::marker pseudo-element represents the automatically generated marker box of a list item.

Like ::before and ::after, ::marker is a tree-abiding pseudo-element, so it always fit within the box tree.

But unlike ::before and ::after, currently it only accepts a small subset of safe properties, because the marker box layout is mostly undefined.

Note this intent only covers ::marker, not ::before::marker nor ::after::marker (see crbug.com/1097992).

name: CSS ::placeholder pseudo element

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Unprefixed version of ::-webkit-input-placeholder.

name: CSS ::target-text pseudo-element

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: A highlight pseudo element to allow authors to style scroll-to-text fragments different from the default UA highlighting.

name: CSS :modal Pseudo Class

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
A pseudo class selector to style dialog element.

The :modal pseudo-class represents an element which is in a state that excludes all interaction with elements outside it until it has been dismissed.

view.notes: While the crbug is only for @font-face, we are aiming at consistent handling of all the name-defining at-rules, including @counter-style.

name: CSS @counter-style rules in shadow trees

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Allows custom counter styles (@counter-style rules) to be defined with shadow trees, and properly referenced within shadow trees or across shadow boundaries.

name: CSS Automatic Hyphenation for Windows/Linux/ChromeOS

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Blink supports `manual` and `none` values of the CSS `hyphens` property since M55, but `auto`, which enables the automatic hyphenation, is supported only on Android and Mac.

This feature enables `hyphens: auto` on Windows, Linux, and ChromeOS by downloading dictionary files used in Android Open Source Project.

The previous feature entry for M55 is https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5642121184804864

name: CSS Blending of background images (mix-blend-mode)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Offers more ways to blend a background image of an element with other background images that are below it and with the element's background color.

name: CSS Box Alignment shorthands

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Shorthand properties to control the alignment behavior along block and inline axes in a single declaration.

name: CSS Color 4 HSL/HSLA syntax

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Update parsing of HSL() and HSLA() to the syntax described in CSS Color 4. The functions were synonymized, along with allowing whitespace to separate the parameters instead of commas, introducing a backslash as a new way to separate the alpha parameter, allowing angles to be specified as the hue, and allowing percent values for the alpha parameter.

name: CSS Color 4 RGB/RGBA syntax

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Update parsing of RGB() and RGBA() to the syntax described in CSS Color 4. The functions were synonymized, along with allowing whitespace to separate the channels instead of commas, introducing a backslash as a new way to separate the alpha parameter, and allowing percent values for the alpha parameter.

view.notes: Development of the color-scheme property in progress. At least blocker issues are being fixed.

name: CSS Color Adjust: 'only' keyword for color-scheme

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The 'only' keyword has been re-added to the specification for color-scheme as a way of per-element opt-out of color-scheme override like forced darkening.

div { color-scheme: light } will force the div element into color-scheme dark and apply forced darkening.
div { color-scheme: only light } will keep the color-scheme for the element light and opt-out of forced darkening.

view.notes:
Mozilla were originally opposed to support a used 'dark' value when the preferred scheme was 'light' because user agents using system form control rendering would not be able to use dark themed controls when the system preference was a light, which led to the spec originally being written as it was.

The plan for Firefox is to move away from system controls:
https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/3881#issuecomment-634463620

From the CSSWG meeting notes for this resolution:
"emilio: uneasy about overwriting user preference. Not really objecting"
'only' still has a separate meaning in Safari for opting out of UA color transformations.

name: CSS Color Adjust: Remove 'only' and support used 'dark' for preferred 'light' for color-scheme

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The color-scheme property from CSS Color Adjustment level 1 spec changed in two ways.

1. The 'only' keyword is no longer special and is treated as a <custom-ident> as any other unknown color-scheme. The 'only' keyword was previously only allowed in combination with 'light', but had otherwise no effect in Chrome.

2. 'color-scheme: dark' will have a used value of 'dark' even when preferred color-scheme is 'light'. 'color-scheme: light dark' still has a used values based on the preferred scheme.

name: CSS Color Adjust: color-scheme meta tag

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Many operating systems now have a "dark mode" preference. Some browsers already offer an option to transform webpages into a dark theme. The prefers-color-scheme media query is a way for an author to support their own dark theme, so they have full control over their own experience. The meta tag is needed so that a site can explicitly opt-in and say that they fully support a dark theme and that the browser should load a different UA sheet and not ever apply transformations.

view.notes: WebKit has an experimental implementation of the same property with a different name (supported-color-schemes).

name: CSS Color Adjust: color-scheme property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Let the author opt-in to follow the preferred color scheme when rendering UI elements such as default colors of form controls and scrollbars as well as the used values of the CSS system colors.

view.notes: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Firefox/Releases/3.5/ICC_color_correction_in_Firefox
Several partners (Adobe, for example) have expressed interest in the new color API.

name: CSS Color Module Level 4 and color-mix()

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: All features described in CSS Color 4 (https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-4/) are now enabled! This includes four device-independent color types (lab, Oklab, lch and Oklch), the color() function and user-defined color spaces for gradients and animations. The incredibly useful color-mix() function from CSS Color 5 (https://www.w3.org/TR/css-color-5/#color-mix) has also been included as a bonus!

name: CSS Conditional Rules

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Support for the @supports at-rule and the "window.CSS.supports()" API

name: CSS Containment

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: A primitive for isolating style, layout, and paint. This allows authors to explicitly opt into a set of restrictions that enables user agent optimizations.

name: CSS Custom Properties (CSS Variables)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Introduces cascading variables as a new primitive value type that is accepted by all CSS properties, and custom properties for defining them.

name: CSS Filters

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Apply (SVG-like) filter effects to arbitrary DOM elements.

name: CSS Flexbox

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: A CSS box model optimized for user interface design. In the flex layout model, the children of a flex container can be laid out in any direction, and can "flex" their sizes, either growing to fill unused space or shrinking to avoid overflowing the parent.

name: CSS Flexbox: New behavior for absolute-positioned children

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
A previous version of the Flexbox spec set the static position of abspos children as if they were a 0x0 flex item. However, the latest version of the spec takes them fully out of flow and sets the static position based on align and justify properties.

(The static position is used when there are no top: or left: or related properties used to position the absolute-positioned element. See the sample below.)

view.notes: Firefox passes all those tests.
19 stars on the bug

name: CSS Flexbox: support alignment keywords start, end, self-start, self-end, left, right

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Make flexbox and flex items obey the positional alignment keywords from https://drafts.csswg.org/css-align-3/#positional-values.

Flexbox previously only obeyed center, flex-start, and flex-end. The additional alignment keywords (start, end, self-start, self-end, left, right) allow authors to more easily align the flex items in the face of varying writing modes and flex flows.

name: CSS Font Loading

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: A feature that enables applications to know if a web font is really loaded.

name: CSS Font Loading API - FontFaceSet interface

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Update FontFaceSet to confirm the latest spec.
Now, FontFaceSet behaves as setlike<FontFace> with entries(), keys(), values(), and iterator.
(crbug.com/392075)

Also add() and remove() are changed not to throw InvalidModificationError on handling CSS-connected FontFaces.
(crbug.com/510346)

name: CSS Gradients

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Gradients provide a method to, over a customizable amount of space, transition from one color to another.

name: CSS Grid Layout

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: A two-dimensional grid-based layout system, optimized for user interface design.

view.notes: No active development since 2017.

Needs to use prefix version `-webkit-initial-letter`.
Supports only an integer size.
No `drop` and `raise` keyword support.

It’s implemented only in Safari, but the usage is high.
 * 40.2% usage ratio according to CSS2021 Usage Overview[1].
 * 23.9% have used it according to CSS2021 Typography features[2].

[1] https://2021.stateofcss.com/en-US/features/#features_overview
[2] https://2021.stateofcss.com/en-US/features/typography/#initial_letter

name: CSS Initial Letters

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Enables a typographic decoration called "initial letter" or "drop caps." Initial letters are large, decorative letters that have been used to start new sections of text since before the invention of printing. In fact, their use predates lowercase letters entirely.

name: CSS Intrinsic Sizing

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Extends the CSS sizing properties with keywords that represent content-based "intrinsic" sizes and context-based "extrinsic" sizes, allowing CSS to more easily describe boxes that fit their content or fit into a particular layout context.

(Note that the "fill" keyword is only shipping prefixed so far, pending CSSWG agreement to unprefix)

name: CSS Masking

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Allows hiding of portions of a visible elements.

name: CSS Motion Path

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Motion paths allow authors to animate any graphical object along an author-specified path.

The following CSS properties are defined:
motion-offset
motion-path
motion-rotation
motion (shorthand)

name: CSS Multi-column (new implementation)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Ship the flow thread based multicol implementation, so that we eventually can bring Blink's multicol support to a level that matches other engines' (Presto and Trident).

name: CSS Nesting

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Add the ability to nest CSS style rules inside other style rules, combining selectors from the outer with the inner rule for increasing modularity and maintainability of style sheets.

name: CSS Overflow for replaced elements

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: This change allows developers to use the existing `overflow` property with replaced elements that paint outside the content-box. Paired with `object-view-box` this can be used to create an image with a custom glow or shadow applied, with proper ink-overflow behavior like a CSS shadow would have.

view.notes: Long discussion of scrollbar-gutter at the CSSWG, citing developer need for an easier way to reason about layout when content grows or shrinks.

name: CSS Overflow: scrollbar-gutter

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The "scrollbar-gutter" property provides control over the presence of scrollbar gutters (the space which may be reserved to display a scrollbar), allowing authors to prevent layout changes as content expands while avoiding unwanted visuals when scrolling isn't needed.

Note that the presence of the scrollbars themselves is determined by the "overflow" property and the decision of whether to use classical or overlay scrollbars is up to the User Agent.

name: CSS Paint API (Houdini)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: CSS Paint API defines a new callback which is designed to allow developers to write code which produces a CSS <image> during the paint phase of the rendering engine.

name: CSS Properties and Values API Level 1 (Houdini)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The CSS Properties and Values API spec defines a registerProperty() function which can be called from JavaScript to register typed and animatable custom CSS properties. This API expands the existing CSS custom properties to improve usability of other Houdini APIs. Being able to animate these and customize inheritance and initial values makes it more useful for custom layout/paint, and having types associated with these allows the typed object mode to work more effectively with custom properties.

name: CSS Root Font Units: 'rex', 'rch', 'ric', 'rlh'

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Adds root font units.

Previously, only 'rem' has been supported in Chrome. This feature adds root element variants of ex, ch, ic, and lh.

view.notes:
Firefox is shipping an older (incompatible) version of css-snappoints but they are working on updating it.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Scroll_Snap_Points

name: CSS Scroll Snap Points

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The CSS scroll snap specification introduces snap points as a way to "enforce the scroll offsets that a scroll container's visual viewport may end at after a scrolling operation has completed". Scroll snapping applies to both user scroll operations such as touch, wheel scrolling, or scrollbar dragging, and programmatic scroll operations such as Element.scrollTo(). This improves the user experience by allowing scrollable zones to easily stop at predefined points.

name: CSS Selectors 4 Pseudo-Class :any-link

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The :any-link pseudo-class represents an element that acts as the source anchor of a hyperlink.

name: CSS Selectors 4 Pseudo-Class :focus-visible

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The :focus-visible pseudo-class makes it easier for developers to create focus styles that appropriately match the user's input modality. It is designed to help prevent a common anti-pattern where developers remove focus outlines for mouse users, and inadvertently make their sites inaccessible to keyboard users.

name: CSS Selectors 4 Pseudo-Class :nth-child(an + b of S)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Extend :nth-child(an + b) to take a selector, and the same with :nth-last-child. So e.g. :nth-child(3 of .c) is the third .c under a given parent. (This is not the same as .c:nth-child(3), which is a .c that must also be the third element under a given parent.)

name: CSS Selectors 4 Pseudo-Class :where()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The Specificity-adjustment pseudo-class, :where(), is a functional pseudo-class with the same syntax and functionality as :is(). Unlike :is(), neither the :where() pseudo-class, nor any of its arguments contribute to the specificity of the selector — its specificity is always zero.

name: CSS Selectors 4 Pseudo-Classes :is(), :where()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The matches-any pseudo-class, :is(), is a functional pseudo-class taking a selector list as its argument. It represents an element that is represented by its argument.

name: CSS Selectors 4: Complex :not()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Allows complex selectors inside the :not() pseudo class, such as :not(.a + .b .c).

name: CSS Shapes Module Level 1

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
CSS Shapes allows one to specify a geometric "shape-outside" for a 
float.  Content will wrap around the float's shape-outside, instead of 
its rectangular boundary. The shape-outside property can be specified 
with a geometric primitive, like an ellipse or a polygon, or by the 
pixels of an image's alpha channel whose values are greater than 
shape-image-threshold. A shape-outside's boundary can be uniformly 
expanded with the shape-margin property.

name: CSS Transition Events

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The CSS Transitions specification specifies that transition events are sent when a transition is enqueued, starts, ends, or is canceled as transitionrun, transitionstart, transitionend, and transitioncancel respectively.

These events mirror the CSS animation events which allow developers to observe CSS animations.

name: CSS Trigonometric functions

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Add trigonometric functions sin(), cos(), tan(), asin(), acos(), atan(), atan2() to CSS math expressions.

MDN: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/CSS_Functions#trigonometric_functions

name: CSS Typed OM (Houdini)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The new CSSOM provides typed style access for developers. This will  generally improve performance primarily by removing the need to do lots of string parsing. In addition to this, it will enable performant development of various new Houdini specifications (including custom properties, layout and paint).

Only a subset of CSS properties are supported for now:
https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/third_party/WebKit/Source/core/css/cssom/README.md

name: CSS UI: caret-color property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: This property allows coloring the insertion caret.

name: CSS Values and Units Module Level 4: Small/Large/Dynamic/Logical viewport units

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Support for sv* units, lv* units, dv* units and the logical vi/vb units.

view.notes:
https://justmarkup.com/articles/2019-01-28-a-look-at-css-hyphenation-in-2019/#too-much-hyphenation
https://generatedcontent.org/post/44751461516/finer-grained-control-of-hyphenation-with-css4
https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=924069
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1521723

Shipping the old syntax properties `hyphenate-limit-{before,after}` with the `-webkit-` prefix.
WebKit standard positions: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/79

name: CSS `hyphenate-limit-chars` property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Specifies the minimum number of characters in a hyphenated word. When applying the hyphenation, the optimal minimum number of characters in the word, before the hyphen, or after the hyphen can vary by the design of the page, or by the language. This property allows the finer grained control of the hyphenation.

name: CSS `text` properties

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: CSS properties used for manipulating text (decoration, line breaking, processing model...)

view.notes: behind the flag

name: CSS animation-composition property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Implement animation-composition property

name: CSS aspect-ratio interpolation

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The aspect-ratio property allows automatically computing the other dimension if only one of width and height is specified on any element. This property was originally launched as non-interpolable (meaning that it would snap to the target value) when animated.

This feature provides smooth interpolation from one aspect ratio to another.

name: CSS aspect-ratio property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Normally, only certain replaced elements have an aspect ratio, particularly images. For them, if only one of width and height is specified, the other can be computed from it using the intrinsic aspect ratio.

This property allows explicitly specifying an aspect ratio for any other element to get similar behavior.

name: CSS backdrop-filter property

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: The backdrop-filter CSS property applies one or more filters to the "backdrop" of an element. The "backdrop" basically means all of the painted content that lies behind the element. This allows designers to construct "frosted glass" dialog boxes, video overlays, translucent navigation headers, and more.

name: CSS border-image-repeat: space support

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Previously, "space" was implemented the same as "repeat".

name: CSS border-image: respect border style

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Blink will begin to require a border style in order to paint border images. This has always been required by the spec, but has not been enforced. In order to not be affected by this change, add e.g. 'border-style:solid' where border-image is used.

name: CSS calc()

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. width: calc(100% - 3em)

name: CSS calc() in media queries

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: According to the CSS Values 4 spec, math functions such as calc() should be allowed wherever individual CSS values such as numbers are allowed. However, calc() expressions are not currently parsed in media queries. This change would introduce support for parsing calc() expressions inside of media queries.

name: CSS cascade layers

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: CSS cascade layers (@layer rule and layered @import syntax) provide a structured way to organize and balance concerns within a single origin. Rules within a single cascade layer cascade together without interleaving with style rules outside the layer. This allows authors to achieve a certain cascade ordering for same-origin rules in a proper way.

name: CSS column-fill property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: column-fill is the one missing CSS property from the multicol spec (not counting break-after, break-before or break-inside, which really belong in a more generic spec for fragmentation). This property is used to tell the engine whether columns should be balanced or not. If they are balanced, each column gets similar amounts of content inside. If they are not balanced, each column will be filled to the height of the multicol container, until we run out of content.

name: CSS conic-gradient

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Support was added for CSS conic (angular/sweep) gradients. Conic gradients allow color transitions around a center rather than radiating from it. This allows, for example, a web developer to create a hue wheel using only two CSS properties.

view.notes: Note that the issue has 2 IRC logs from CSSWG discussing the feature and resolving on names/values.
Note that the issue has 2 IRC logs from CSSWG discussing the feature and resolving on names/values.
Note that the issue has 2 IRC logs from CSSWG discussing the feature and resolving on names/values.

name: CSS contain-intrinsic-size

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The contain-intrinsic-size property allows developers to specify a placeholder size which would be used while contain: size is applied. With contain-intrinsic-size specified, elements lay out as if they had a single child with fixed size (specified by contain-intrinsic-size) unless they have an explicit width/height.

This is helpful when size containment may be dynamically added/removed so that there is a fallback size during size containment but a content-based size during regular sizing.

view.notes: The early position from Firefox considered previous iterations of this feature 'harmful'. We have worked extensively with Mozilla to address the feedback that caused this position, and believe we have addressed all of it. We have requested an updated position, but so far there has been no official update.
We have sent a request for position, but there has been no signals so far.

We have been working with Facebook on the adoption of the 'auto' and 'hidden' values for content-visibility and the feedback from their prototype has been positive. Another site that participated in the origin trial found it an easy way to get a big performance win.

name: CSS content-visibility property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Adds a CSS property called content-visibility, which allows automatic or script management of content visibility. When hidden, the element's contents (subtree or replaced element contents) are not drawn or hit-tested and have CSS containment applied, allowing for rendering optimizations. The 'auto' keyword allows for the user-agent to manage content visibility based on proximity to the viewport, whereas 'hidden' keyword allows full script control of content visibility.

view.notes: Shipped in Firefox 68 according to MDN

name: CSS counter-set

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: CSS counter-set is an additional property introduced in css-lists-3 to control counters by setting an existing counter to a specified value. This builds upon other implemented counter control properties, specifically counter-reset (which creates a new counter with a specified value) and counter-increment (which increments an existing counter by a specified amount).

view.notes: Other than image symbols and 'speak-as: spell-out', Firefox has fully shipped the feature.

name: CSS custom counter styles

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The CSS @counter-style rule allows web authors to specify and use custom counter styles in list markers and CSS counters. This helps web internationalization.

view.notes: In the past Apple was positive about adding support for the rest of the spec (https://lists.webkit.org/pipermail/webkit-dev/2018-August/030086.html).

name: CSS flow-relative Corner Rounding properties

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Support the flow-relative Corner Rounding properties following CSS Logical Properties and Values spec. Specifically, the following logical properties are included: border-start-start-radius, border-start-end-radius, border-end-start-radius, and border-end-end-radius.

The flow-relative Corner Rounding properties (border-*-radius) will allow to set top-left, bottom-left, top-right and bottom-right box corners with logical mappings rather than physical properties.

name: CSS flow-relative shorthand and offset properties

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Ship the already implemented properties introduced by CSS Logical Properties.
Specifically:
 - border-block, border-block-color, border-block-style, border-block-width
 - border-inline, border-inline-color, border-inline-style, border-inline-width
 - inset-block-start, inset-block-end, inset-inline-start, inset-inline-end
 - inset, inset-block, inset-inline
 - margin-block, margin-inline
 - padding-block, padding-inline

name: CSS font-display

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Adds the @font-face descriptor and a corresponding property for controlling how a downloadable font renders before it is fully loaded.

name: CSS font-feature-settings

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
This property provides low-level control over OpenType font features. It is intended as a way of providing access to font features that are not widely used but are needed for a particular use case.

Currently available with the -webkit prefix. This is about shipping the unprefixed version AND deprecating the prefix version.

name: CSS font-kerning

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: A CSS property to control text kerning.

name: CSS font-stretch

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Add support the the CSS font-stretch property.

name: CSS font-variant-east-asian

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Add support for font-variant-east-asian and respective mapping for the font: shorthand and the font-variant: shorthand.

name: CSS font-variant-ligatures

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: A CSS property to control ligatures in text.

name: CSS gradient color stop double-position syntax

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Add support for CSS Image Values 4 color stop position syntax.

Currently, repeating colors require explicit positions, for example:

  linear-gradient(45deg, black 25%, black 50%, white 50%, white 75%)

To simplify the definition of solid color bands, css-images-4 allows specifying up to two positions for a color:

  linear-gradient(45deg, black 25% 50%, white 50% 75%)

name: CSS grid-template properties interpolation

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
In CSS Grid, the grid-template-columns and grid-template-rows properties allow developers to define line names and track sizing of grid columns and rows, respectively. Supporting interpolation for these properties will allow grid layouts to smoothly transition between states, instead of snapping at the halfway point of an animation or transition.

Web developers can use this functionality to achieve specific interactive effects.

name: CSS hyphens property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
This CSS property controls automatic hyphenations. The automatic hyphenation is strongly demanded as seen in crbug.com/47083, and is already supported by all other major browsers.

Blink enables the following values on all platforms:

"manual" - the initial value.
"none" - disables soft hyphens.

and the following value on Android and Mac:

"auto" - enables the automatic hyphenation for languages where the underlying operating system has dictionaries.

name: CSS logical flow relative margins, paddings and borders

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Chrome now implements logical margin, padding, and border CSS properties using standard names, specifically margin-{block,inline}-{start,end}, padding-{block,inline}-{start,end} and border-{block,inline}-{start,end}-{width,style,color}. These capabilities were previously supported through -webkit prefixes and non-standard names. Shorthand properties are only added for border-{block,inline}-{start,end}.

name: CSS logical height and width

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Implement {inline-,block-}size and {min-,max-}{inline-,block-}size, which are introduced by CSS Logical Properties.
The related properties are:  inline-size, block-size , min-inline-size,min-block-size, max-inline-size, max-block-size   
Provide the author with the ability to control layout through logical, rather than physical, direction and dimension mappings.

view.notes:
min() and max() are were shipped in Safari 11.1 and iOS 11.2. clamp() is not shipped yet but is enabled in Safari TP 97.
https://webkit.org/blog/9672/release-notes-for-safari-technology-preview-97/

name: CSS min(), max() and clamp()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Adds the comparison functions min(), max(), and clamp() to math expressions for numeric CSS values.

view.notes: Awaiting response to https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/541, but expected to be Positive based on prior conversations.
Awaiting response to https://lists.webkit.org/pipermail/webkit-dev/2021-June/031901.html
Very positive feedback in the original GitHub issue https://github.com/WICG/webcomponents/issues/759. Lit developer community is strongly in favor.

name: CSS module scripts

docs: This design doc covers how the feature was implemented using Synthetic Modules: https://github.com/MicrosoftEdge/MSEdgeExplainers/blob/main/SyntheticModules/designDoc.md

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
CSS Module Scripts are an extension of the ES Script Modules system that allows web developers to load CSS into a component definition in a manner that interacts seamlessly with other module types:

import styleSheet from "./styles.css" assert { type: "css" };

name: CSS object-fit and object-position

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: CSS properties that control the position and size of replaced content within the content box

view.notes:
This property is a pre-requisite for Shared Element Transitions which has positive feedback from developers : https://twitter.com/jaffathecake/status/1524782819431555074?t=itU6B0wo6SbjomGiSKLmGQ&s=19

Multiple customers who are excited about SET need this feature to achieve their desired UX, since their designs have visual overflows such as shadows.

name: CSS object-view-box

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: object-view-box allows the author to specify a subset within an image that should draw within the content box of the target replaced element. This enables an author to create an image with a custom glow or shadow applied, with proper ink-overflow behavior like a CSS shadow would have.

name: CSS overscroll-behavior

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: CSS `overscroll-behavior` allows developers to decide the browser's behavior once a scroller has reached its full extent. The unused delta can be propagated to the parent causing scroll chaining, create a glow/bounce effect without chaining, or just get consumed silently. This would be a standardization of "-ms-scroll-chaining" with some modification.

name: CSS position: sticky

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: position: sticky is a new way to position elements and is conceptually similar to position: fixed. The difference is that a stickily positioned element behaves like position: relative within its parent, until a given offset threshold is met.

name: CSS prefers-reduced-motion media query

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Support will be added for the CSS prefers-reduced-motion media query. The prefers-reduced-motion media query detects whether the user has requested that the system minimize the amount of motion it uses; in particular motion-based animation. This is for users who either require or prefer minimized motion. For example people with vestibular disorders often desire animation motion to be kept to a minimum.

view.notes: Shipped in Firefox 70 according to MDN.
Not responded to reported issue: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=215646

name: CSS quotes property - support 'auto' value

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Support 'auto' for the 'quotes' property.

CSS2 specified the initial value for 'quotes' as UA dependent, but WebKit and Blink returns an invalid value (empty string) which will not round-trip. Setting it to the empty string will remove the declaration instead of setting it to the initial value. css-content-3 instead uses an 'auto' keyword for the default UA behavior.

name: CSS text-size-adjust

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The text-size-adjust property lets authors control and disable the text autosizing feature which increases font sizes on mobile.

name: CSS touch-action

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: New CSS property to enable websites to declaratively state how touches should be handled for purposes of scrolling and zooming.

name: CSS transform-box

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The transform-box property allows defining which reference box to use when computing 'transform' and 'transform-origin'. It currently only has an effect on SVG elements.

name: CSS will-change

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Adds a will-change CSS property, that can be used to signal that a particular property is likely to be changed in the future, or that an element’s content is likely to change.

name: CSS.escape()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: `CSS.escape()` serializes a string as a CSS identifier. This enables developers to easily and securely do things like escaping a string for use as part of a selector.

name: CSS3 Text Decorations

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
CSS3 Text Decoration specification provides new properties that implements new text decoration styling features such as lines, color and style. As the specification says:

"CSS Levels 1 and 2 only defined very basic line decorations (underlines, overlines, and strike-throughs) appropriate to Western typographical traditions. Level 3 of this module adds the ability to change the color, style, position, [...]"

This Chromestatus entry consists of the 
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-text-decor-2

name: CSS4 :focus-within pseudo-class

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The :focus-within pseudo-class applies to elements for which the :focus pseudo class applies.

An element also matches :focus-within if one of its descendants in the flat tree (including non-element nodes, such as text nodes) matches the conditions for matching :focus.

name: CSS4 text-decoration-skip-ink

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
CSS Text Decoration 4: property controls how overlines and underlines are drawn when they cross over a glyph.

With the initial, default value "auto" decoration lines skip over where glyphs are drawn: interrupt the decoration line to let the shape of the text show through where the text decoration would otherwise cross over a glyph. The UA must also skip a small distance to either side of the glyph outline.

To disable this behavior, use `text-decoration-skip-ink: none`

name: CSS: New names for motion path properties

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Motion paths allow authors to animate any graphical object along an author-specified path.

The CSS properties are being named: offset-path offset-distance offset-rotate.



From Chrome 55, offset-path and offset-distance are supported. offset-rotate will become available in Chrome 56.

name: CSS: Use the response URL as the base URL

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The base URL of stylesheets is now the response URL of the stylesheet rather than the request URL. These are only different if a service worker provided the response. If the service worker does respondWith(fetch(url)), the base URL becomes url.

Also, to align with the specification, stylesheets that (a) failed to load due to network error, or (b) loaded via a redirect from cross-origin back to same-origin are considered cross-origin.

name: CSSConditionRule interface

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The CSSConditionRule interface inherits from CSSGroupingRule. CSSMediaRule and CSSSupportsRule both inherit from CSSConditionRule. Before the introduction of CSSConditionRule in Blink, CSSMediaRule inherited from CSSGroupingRule, while CSSSupportsRule inherited from CSSRule and duplicated the members of CSSGroupingRule.

name: CSSGroupingRule

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The CSSGroupingRule interface represents an at-rule that contains other rules nested inside itself. Per spec, CSSMediaRule and CSSPageRule inherit from CSSGroupingRule.

name: CSSNamespaceRule

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The CSSNamespaceRule interface represents an at-rule for declaring the default namespace and binding namespaces to namespace prefixes.

name: CSSOM Document.elementsFromPoint API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: An API on Document for returning the sequence of elements under a point.

name: CSSOM View smooth scroll API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Adds an optional argument to existing scroll APIs that specifies whether scrolling should be smooth. Also adds a CSS property for this.

view.notes:
Have attempted to contact Mozilla's replacement for J. C. Jones but to no avail. Mozilla are no longer active in the W3C WG either.

Microsoft have, in the past, contributed security key functionality to Firefox and may do so again.
(One unrelated web developer reached out to us about wanting this.)

name: CTAP2 credBlob extension

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
CTAP is the protocol used between computers and security keys. CTAP 2.1 defines[1] a security key extension called credBlob that is designed to store a hash value that can be used to authenticate externally provided data.

This feature involves plumbing that value through WebAuthn to let the security key see it.

[1] https://fidoalliance.org/specs/fido-v2.1-rd-20210309/fido-client-to-authenticator-protocol-v2.1-rd-20210309.html#sctn-credBlob-extension

name: Cache API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The Cache API allow authors to fully and conveniently manage their content caches for offline use. An origin can have multiple, named Cache objects which are accessible via workers and document scripts.

name: Cache API (global scope)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The Cache API allows authors to fully and conveniently manage their content caches for offline use. An origin can have multiple, named Cache objects.

This API is already available in a Service Worker context. This entry is to make it available globally (=> accessible from a document context).

name: Cache API is restricted to secure origins

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Cache API exposed to window and worker contexts (not just service worker) shipped in Chrome 43. As of Chrome 46, the API is restricted to secure origins (HTTPS only), per https://github.com/slightlyoff/ServiceWorker/issues/709

name: Cache.add()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: add() takes a RequestInfo object, fetches it and adds the response object into this Cache object.

name: Cache.addAll()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: addAll() takes an array of RequestInfo objects, fetches them and adds the response objects into this Cache object.

name: Cache.matchAll()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: matchAll() returns a promise to be resolved with an array of all matched responses in the Cache object.

name: CacheStorage CacheQueryOptions support

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: CacheQueryOptions (ignoreMethod, ignoreVary, ignoreQuery, and cacheName) have been exposed but worked inconsistently across the various CacheStorage methods. As of M54 they are all supported as specified.

name: Call capture event listeners in capturing phase at shadow hosts

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Call capture event listeners in capturing phase at shadow hosts.

Per the discussion of https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/685, Blink will align the event dispatch behavior to other browsers; Call capture event listeners in capturing phase at shadow hosts.

name: Canvas

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Provides an API to draw 2D graphics

view.notes: This spec has been developed in close cooperation with Mozilla engineers.
Patches started landing against the bug immediately after it was filed.

name: Canvas color management

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Formalize that the default color space for 2D canvases and ImageData is sRGB. Clarify that 2D canvas is fully color managed (that all inputs are converted to the canvas color space). These were previously convention and not clearly specified.

Add parameters to specify a non-sRGB color space when creating a 2D canvas or an ImageData. Add support for the Display P3 color space for these parameters.

name: Canvas context "alpha" attribute

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allow the specification of a 2D canvas with an opaque backing store (alpha: false). Speeds up compositing. Enables LCD text anti-aliasing.

name: Capability Delegation

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Capability delegation means allowing a frame to relinquish its ability to call a restricted API and transfer the ability to another (sub)frame it trusts.

If an app wants to delegate its ability to call a restricted JS capability (e.g. popups, fullscreen, etc) to a known+trusted third-party frame, the app would utilize a Capability Delegation API to "transfer" the ability to the target frame in a time-constrained manner (unlike static mechanisms like <iframe allow> attributes).

view.notes:
Engaged in discussions in the W3C and approved the adoption of this document.

Mozilla is currently engaged in discussion over issue #11. Mozilla suggests setCaptureHandleConfig() should only be callable once; we disagree, and believe it should be callable multiple times. Theoretically speaking, if Mozilla's proposed change is accepted, then in order to be spec-compliant, Chrome would have to change its implementation and raise an exception if the method is called multiple times. However:
* If calling multiple times is proven common, then we'll have strong arguments against Mozilla's proposed change, and we'll be more likely to convince them.
* If calling multiple times is rare, then it will be relatively painless to change Chrome's implementation.

In either case, we have a reasonable way forward regardless of how things turn out.
Engaged in discussions in the W3C and approved the adoption of this document.
Strong positive signals from Google, Microsoft, Citrix, Zoom, RingCentral and Jitsi. See link above for specific links.

name: Capture Handle

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
We introduce a mechanism that allows an application to opt-in to exposing certain information to other applications which are video-capturing it. This allows collaboration between capturing and captured applications.

For example, a VC application that's video-capturing a tab where a presentation application lives, could expose user-facing controls in the VC tab for navigating the presentation in the captured tab.

name: Case-insensitive Attribute Selector Matching

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: An additional modifier ('i') for attribute selectors, that allows an author to match an attribute (ASCII) case-insensitively.

name: Change MediaSettingsRange & PhotoCapabilities interfaces to dictionaries

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Aggregates and logs media settings ranges and photo capabilities in JSON.


Changing MediaSettingsRange and PhotoCapabilities interfaces to dictionaries will improve developer ergonomics by allowing web developers to easily log and aggregate exposureCompensation, exposureTime, colorTemperature, iso, brightness, contrast, saturation, sharpness, focusDistance, pan, tilt, zoom, and photo capabilities (redEyeReduction, imageHeight, imageWidth, fillLightMode).

name: Change click, auxclick and contextmenu event types to PointerEvent

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Change “click”, “contextmenu”, “auxclick” events to PointerEvent (instead of MouseEvent) to let developers: distinguish between mouse, pen and individual fingers in a multitouch interaction through pointerType and pointerId attributes, and utilize fractional event coordinates for high precision use cases.

name: Child-indexed pseudo-classes matching elements without a parent

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Change how the child-indexed pseudo-class selectors are matched so they also match elements without a parent.

This is a change in the spec from selectors-3 to selectors-4. The reasoning for this is explained in the spec.

view.notes:
Firefox is tracking the implementation of the feature.

Also, see https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/498#issuecomment-796586704 for evidence that Mozilla considers all Stage 3 TC39 proposals to be "positive".
No response yet.

name: Class static initializer blocks

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

name: Classes (ES6)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Language support for classes.

In 42, shipped in strict mode. In 49, shipped outside of strict mode as well.

name: Clear window name for cross-site navigations that switches browsing context group

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The value of the window.name property is currently preserved throughout the lifetime of a tab, even with navigation that switches browsing context groups, which can leak information and potentially be used as a tracking vector. Clear the window.name property in this case addresses this issue. This should be a low risk change since looking up a browsing context by name already does not work if it's in another browsing context group, so the name isn't actually useful.

name: Clear-Site-Data header

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
A ‘Clear-Site-Data’ HTTP header prompts the user agent to clear browsing data associated with the requesting website. The supported browsing data types are cookies, storage (i.e. “site data”), and cache.

This is a privacy and security enhancing feature. A sensitive website can trigger local data deletion after the user signs out. A website dealing with a persistent XSS attack can use this to ‘reset’ itself to a clean state.

name: Client Hints persistency in Android WebView

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: We aim to add support for persistent Client Hints to Android Webview for parity with the rest of the platform. For more details on the Client Hints system see: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Client_hints

name: Client.type

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The type read-only property of the Client interface indicates the type of client the service worker is controlling.

name: Clipboard: Preserve PNG metadata

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Read unsanitized PNGs from the system clipboard. This will apply to both DataTransfer and the Async Clipboard API (navigator.clipboard.read()).

view.notes: It appears that mozilla have a long outstanding request to add support for this feature https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1087675 similar to crbug.com/487266

name: Clipboard: read-only files support

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

name: ClipboardEvent Constructor

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This entry tracks exposing ClipboardEvent constructor.

name: Compositing and Blending in Canvas 2D

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The canvas 2d context has the globalCompositeOperation attribute that is used to set the current compositing and blending operator.

view.notes: Comments are generally positive, but a formal position has not been reached yet.
Most responses are positive. Many developers want zstd or brotli support. A minority of developers question the need for the API.

name: Compression Streams

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Provides a means of performing gzip and deflate compression from JavaScript using streams. This covers two interfaces: CompressionStream and DecompressionStream.

view.notes: Now turned on by default

name: Compute img/video aspect ratio from width and height HTML attributes

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Computes the aspect ratio of an image using the HTML width and height attributes so that it can be used for sizing an image using CSS before it loads.

name: Computed Property Names (ES6)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Allows expression for property names in object literals and class literals

name: Constructible & Subclassable EventTarget

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Make EventTarget constructor callable, allowing them to be constructed on their own or be subclassed.

name: Constructible Stylesheets

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The API provides a way to create CSSStyleSheet objects from script without needing <style> or <link> elements. Script can optionally modify the stylesheet by adding, removing, or replacing rules in it. Each stylesheet object can then be adopted/used in multiple tree scopes (document/shadow roots). Not only does this reduce memory duplication, it also allows an element’s styles to be modified in a single location.

name: Constructor for DataTransfer

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

name: Consume User Activation After Entering FullScreen Mode

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: To prevent a user activation from opening more than one fullscreen window, entering fullscreen will consume the user activation.

view.notes: https://github.com/WICG/contact-api/issues/20

name: Contacts API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Provides a way for websites to request information about the user’s contact(s) and provides a UI for the user to share those details in a way that makes it clear what is being shared with the website. This could be used for bootstrapping a friends list on a social network or (in an email/messaging application) to select message recipients.

view.notes: See implementation activity reachable from that bug.

name: Container Queries

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Container Queries allow authors to style elements according to the size of a container element.

It's similar to a @media query, except it evaluates against the size of a container instead of the size of the viewport.

name: Content Indexing API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allows websites to register offline enabled content in the browser. This allows the browser to improve the offline experience and allow content browsing when the user is offline. This data could also be used to improve on-device search and to augment browsing history.

name: Content Security Policy Level 1

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Allows you to create a whitelist of sources of trusted content, and instructs the browser to only execute or render resources from those sources.

name: Content Security Policy Level 2

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: An evolution of the Content Security Policy specification, allowing developers to create a whitelist of sources of trusted content, and instructing the browser to only execute or render resources from those sources.

view.notes: See also the discussion on the issue https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-csp/issues/336
This has been reported as a bug to chrome.

name: Content-Security-Policy delivery via response headers for dedicated workers.

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Dedicated workers should be governed by the Content Security Policy delivered in their script response headers. Chrome incorrectly used to instead apply the Content Security Policy of the owner document.

We would like to change chrome's behaviour to adhere to what is specified.

view.notes: Several large web component developers are strongly positive on this feature and change. See several links in the "Interoperability and Compatibility Risks" section.

name: Convert adoptedStyleSheets to use ObservableArray

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The prior specification for adoptedStyleSheets used a FrozenArray backing array. The spec was recently changed, so that the backing array is an ObservableArray. This makes the API easier to use and understand, since it is a true mutable JS array object. For example, normal array operations such as adoptedStyleSheets.push(sheet) can be used.

name: Cookie Expires/Max-Age attribute upper limit

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: When cookies are set with an explicit Expires/Max-Age attribute the value will now be capped to no more than 400 days in the future. Previously, there was no limit and cookies could expire as much as multiple millennia in the future.

name: Cookie Prefixes

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This feature adds a set of restrictions upon the names which may be used for cookies with specific properties. These restrictions enable user agents to smuggle cookie state to the server within the confines of the existing "Cookie" request header syntax, and limits the ways in which cookies may be abused.

In a nutshell: `__Secure-*` cookies have to have the `Secure` flag, and `__Host-*` cookies have to have `Path=/`, can't have `Domain`, and might require `Secure` (depending on the setter).

view.notes: Cookies are commonly used for login sessions. Cookie Store API will allow Service Workers to react to session state changes and cleanup irrelevant or private cached data.

name: Cookie Store API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The Cookie Store API exposes HTTP cookies to service workers and offers an asynchronous alternative to document.cookie.

name: Cookie size limits

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Enforce limits on the size (in bytes) of cookies set by HTTP responses (Set-Cookie header) and via JS APIs (document.cookie and CookieStore).

name: Cookies Having Independent Partitioned State (CHIPS)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Given that Chrome plans on obsoleting third-party cookies, we want to give developers the ability to use cookies in third-party contexts that are partitioned by top-level site to meet use cases that are not cross-site tracking related (e.g. SaaS embeds, headless CMS, sandbox domains, etc.). In order to do so, we introduce a mechanism to opt-in to having their third-party cookies partitioned by top-level site using a new cookie attribute, Partitioned.

name: Cookies default to SameSite=Lax

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Treat cookies as SameSite=Lax by default if no SameSite attribute is specified. Developers are still able to opt-in to the status quo of unrestricted use by explicitly asserting SameSite=None.

This feature is available as of Chrome 76 by enabling the same-site-by-default-cookies flag.

This feature will be rolled out gradually to Stable users starting July 14, 2020. See https://www.chromium.org/updates/same-site for full timeline and more details.

name: Correct handling of percentages in children of flex items

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Certain flex items should be considered to have definite sizes (see spec URL), and therefore if a child element of a flex item uses percentage sizes, they should work.

name: Crash Reports

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Crash reports are a new type of report available via the Reporting API. These reports indicate that a crash occurred on a page and possibly the reason it occurred (out of memory for example).

name: Create Workers from `data:` URLs

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: HTML specifies that `data:` URLs can be used to create workers with opaque origins. We should support this as a first step towards defining a sandboxing mechanism for Workers (and parity with other browsers).

name: Credential Management API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The API provides a programmatic interface to the browser's credential manager. In short, an origin can request a user's credentials to sign them in, or can ask the browser to save credentials on the user's behalf. Both of these requests are user-mediated.

name: Credential Management API - CredentialsContainer.create

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This feature introduces the CredentialsContainer.create method to the Credential Management API. This method allows for asynchronous creation of Credential objects.

name: Cross Origin Font Loading Restriction

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Aligning with the specification (and other browsers) and blocking cross origin font loading, unless the response include the appropriate CORS headers.

name: Cross-Origin Read Blocking (CORB)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Cross-Origin Read Blocking (CORB) is an algorithm that can identify and block dubious cross-origin resource loads in web browsers before they reach the web page. CORB reduces the risk of leaking sensitive data by keeping it further from cross-origin web pages. In most browsers, it keeps such data out of untrusted script execution contexts. In browsers with Site Isolation, it can keep such data out of untrusted renderer processes entirely, helping even against side channel attacks like Spectre.

name: Cross-Origin Resource Policy

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
“Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy” response header allows http servers to ask the browser to prevent cross-origin or cross-site embedding of the returned resource.  It is complementary to the Cross-Origin Read Blocking feature and is especially valuable for resources not covered by CORB (which only protects HTML, XML and JSON).

“Cross-Origin-Resource-Policy” is currently the only way to protect images against Spectre attacks or against compromised renderers.

name: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Add a new HTTP header that prevents documents and workers from loading non-same-origin requests unless explicitly allowed via CORS or CORP. 

Combined with Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy (COOP), this feature allows documents (and workers) to use powerful APIs such as SharedArrayBuffer.

view.notes: Worth prototyping, but concerns are about the timing in between shipping: COEP:credentialless, Private Network Access (PNA), ORB. See https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/539#issuecomment-914418485

No official replies yet.

Safari is currently implementing COOP/COEP, but have no plan yet about COEP:credentialless variant. https://twitter.com/mikewest/status/1434878018191826948<
Google Earth, Twitter, Zoom, etc... are positive.

name: Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: credentialless

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Introduce Cross-Origin-Embedder-Policy: credentialless. This causes cross-origin no-cors requests to omit credentials (cookies, client certificates, etc). Similarly to COEP:require-corp, it can enable cross-origin isolation.

view.notes: Firefox has implemented this behind the browser.tabs.remote.useCrossOriginOpenerPolicy pref.
Safari 12 shipped an earlier version ("cross-origin-window-policy"), per https://developer.apple.com/safari/whats-new/.

name: Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: The Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy response header provides a way for a document to request a new browsing context group to better isolate itself from other untrustworthy origins.  Optionally, browsers can also choose to place top-level documents in a different process from documents without a matching Cross-Origin-Opener-Policy.

view.notes: Facebook has been successfully using the reporting API in Origin Trial to deploy COOP on their properties.

name: Cross-origin opener policy reporting API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds a reporting API to help developers deploy cross-origin opener policy.

name: Custom Elements v1

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Custom Elements let web authors define their own tags. Chrome shipped an implementation based on the working draft of the spec in M33. The current editor's draft of the spec has significant updates based on web developer and implementer feedback.

view.notes: Highlight API listed in Release 99 notes.
Multiple use cases have been pointed out in this issue. CKEditor has also shown support from the first highlight API explainer.

name: Custom Highlight API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The custom highlight API provides a way for web developers to style the text of arbitrary ranges. This is useful in a variety of scenarios, including editing frameworks that wish to implement their own selection, find-on-page over virtualized documents, multiple selections to represent online collaboration, or spellchecking frameworks.

name: Custom state pseudo class

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The feature lets custom elements expose their states via the :state() CSS pseudo class.

name: Customized built-in elements

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Authors can now create custom elements which inherit from the semantics of native, built-in elements. This is helpful when web authors want to add features to their custom elements, but they cannot be implemented in CSS or JavaScript though the features are available in built-in elements.

name: DIALOG element has display:block style by default

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The default display style of a DIALOG element is changed from inline to block.

name: DOM3 Wheel Events

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Implementation of the standard DOM Level 3 WheelEvent. Currently Blink implements a non standard mousewheel event with a very similar but incompatible API.

name: DOM3 mouseenter & mouseleave Events
