Chrome on Android currently has a touch ACK timeout of 200ms for desktop sites. If the renderer does not respond to a touch event before the timeout delay, the touch sequence is cancelled and any associated gestures are dispatched.

This change restores a touch timeout for sites with a mobile-friendly viewport,  but with a timeout delay of 1 second.

name: Touch-action: pan-up pan-down pan-left pan-right CSS properties

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The touch-action CSS property determines whether touch input may trigger default behavior supplied by user agent. This includes, but is not limited to, behaviors such as panning or zooming.

Additional keywords indicating: pan-up, pan-down, pan-left, pan-right have been added to the specification.

name: Touch-action: pinch-zoom CSS property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Support the touch-action: pinch-zoom CSS property. 

The user agent MAY consider touches that begin on the element for the purposes of continuous zooming and immediately execute the default action instead of waiting for an event handler to not cancel it.

name: Touch.rotationAngle

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The rotation angle, in degrees, of the contact area ellipse defined by Touch.radiusX and Touch.radiusY.

name: Track element

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Add subtitles, captions, screen reader descriptions, chapters and other types of timed metadata to video and audio. Chrome currently supports the WebVTT format for track data.

name: Trailing comma in JavaScript function parameter lists

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
A small modification to JavaScript syntax allows trailing comma in formal parameter lists and in argument lists. For example, all the following become valid:

function f(a, b,) { return a + b }
let g = (a, b,) => a + b
f(1, 2,) + g(3, 4,)

This is expected to be available by default in Chrome 58.

name: Transform list interpolation

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Chrome will improve how CSS transforms are handled to reduce cases where a matrix interpolation fallback is used. An interpolation is an intermediate transformation. Sometimes interpretation of the CSS rule requires falling back to a matrix to accomplish the interpolation, and this can produce visual results other than what the web developer intends. To mitigate this, the spec was changed to reduce the number of situations when this can occur.

name: Treat Document Level Wheel/Mousewheel Event Listeners as Passive

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The wheel/mousewheel event listeners that are registered on document level targets (window.document, window.document.body, or window) will be treated as passive if not specified as otherwise and calling preventDefault() inside such listeners will be ignored. This is the wheel version of the scrolling intervention which is shipped in Chrome 56: https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2017/01/scrolling-intervention

name: Treat file:// URLs as having unique origin

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Similar to sandboxed iframes and data: URLs, treat file:// URLs as having unique origin.

view.notes: Follow the links on this page: https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-trusted-types/wiki/Integrations

name: Trusted Types for DOM Manipulation

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
'Trusted Types' offers an (optional) mechanism for web sites to protect themselves against XSS (cross-site scripting) attacks.It limits the attack surface from potentially the entire code base to a handful of "policies" that a developer can implement and install, and whose usage the browser will then enforce. "Trusted types" then ensure that all risk-ful parts of the DOM can only be used by data that has gone through such a developer-supplied policy.

Release is expected in Chrome 83.

name: Trusted Web Activities

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Trusted Web Activities are a mode of Chrome Custom Tabs without browser UI, available to web content an app developer controls.

We want the modern mobile web (primarily PWAs) to go mainstream. Nevertheless, they make up a small proportion of app experiences on Android today. The vast majority of developers simply haven’t made one yet. TWAs lower the risks of distribution by allowing developers to integrate their PWA into a native app and give PWA developers the same capabilities as native apps.

name: Turn RTCRtpContributingSource from an interface into a dictionary

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The specification requires RTCRtpContributingSource to be a dictionary, but it was previously shipped as an interface. With this change RTCRtpContributingSource will no longer have a prototype and getContributingSources() will create a new set of objects with each call.

name: Typed Arrays

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Buffers for holding binary data and working with WebGL & Audio API: ArrayBuffer, Float32Array , Int16Array, Uint8Array, etc.)

name: U2F Security Key API removal (Cryptotoken Component Extension)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: The Cryptotoken component extension offers a chrome.runtime.sendMessage() API that allows any web site to make requests to a user's FIDO U2F security key. Cryptotoken and its API have been subsumed by the W3C Web Authentication API.

name: UI Events KeyboardEvent |code| attribute

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The KeyboardEvent |code| attribute contains information about the key event that can use used identify the physical key being pressed by the user.

name: UIEvent.sourceCapabilities & InputDeviceCapabilities.firesTouchEvents

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The InputDeviceCapabilities API provides details about the physical device responsible for generating an event. InputDeviceCapabilities.firesTouchEvents returns whether this device dispatches touch events. All types of UIEvent now have their own sourceCapabilities attribute which returns the InputDeviceCapabilities associated with the physical device responsible for them.

name: UIEvents KeyboardEvent |key| attribute

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The KeyboardEvent |key| attribute contains information about the character being generated by the key event.

name: URL

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Expose constructible URL objects that can be manipulated and combined.

name: URL Protocol Handler Registration for PWAs

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Enable web applications to register themselves as handlers of custom URL protocols/schemes using their installation manifest.

name: URL protocol setter: New restrictions for file URLs

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Aligns behavior with the standard in edge cases when changing the URL protocol to or from "file".

Previously, attempting to change the protocol of a URL with credentials or a port to "file" would lead to an invalid URL. Similarly, attempting to change a URL with no host from "file" to "http" would lead to an invalid URL. Now the invalid change will be ignored for consistency with other browsers.

This affects the "protocol" attribute on the URL API, location, and <a> and <area> elements.

name: URL.searchParams readonly attribute

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Access the query portion of a URL by way of a URLSearchParams object.

name: URLPattern

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: URLPattern is a new web API that provides native support for matching URLs given a pattern string.  It is designed to be usable both in javascript directly and by passing patterns to other web platform APIs; e.g. as a service worker scope.

view.notes: This was a web developer community request and the spec/polyfill changes were contributed by an external web developer.

name: URLPattern ignoreCase

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Many client-side JavaScript frameworks currently use case insensitive URL matching.  URLPattern, however, follows URL semantics and treats many parts of the URL as case sensitive.

This feature adds an `ignoreCase` option to the URLPattern that switches all matching operations to case insensitive for that given pattern.

name: URLSearchParams

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The URLSearchParams interface allows developers to (shock!) manipulate the search params of a URL. It also provides a mechanism to POST data via `fetch()` with a urlencoded body vs. the multipart body that `FormData` produces.

name: URLSearchParams: sort() method

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Sorts all name-value pairs stored in a URLSearchParams. Proposed at https://github.com/whatwg/url/issues/26 to improve cache hit rate easily.

name: URLSearchParams: updated constructor

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: URLSearchParams' constructor has been changed in https://github.com/whatwg/url/pull/175. It is now possible to create a new URLSearchParams by passing it any object (e.g. `new URLSearchParams({'foo': 'bar'})`).

view.notes: [1] Both Gecko and WebKit are unlikely to object to this feature specifically, but object to the overall WebUSB API as a whole, hence it doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.

[1] Both Gecko and WebKit are unlikely to object to this feature specifically, but object to the overall WebUSB API as a whole, hence it doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.

name: USBDevice forget()

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Following the recent HIDDevice forget() addition[1] to the web platform, the USBDevice forget() method allows web developers to voluntarily revoke a permission to a USBDevice that was granted by a user.

[1] https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/Fk-IJF63UWc

name: Unicode property escapes in regular expressions

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The Unicode Standard assigns various properties and property values to every symbol. For example, to get the set of symbols that are used exclusively in the Greek script, search the Unicode database for symbols whose Script property is set to Greek.

Unicode property escapes are a new type of escape sequence available in regular expressions that have the `u` flag set. They enable querying the Unicode database for certain properties and values.

E.g. `/\p{Script=Greek}/u.test('π') === true`

name: Unified touch adjustment

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Touch adjustment will adjust the TouchEvent and the corresponding PointerEvent target to a best target within the touch area. TouchEvent coordinates will not be changed.

name: Unprefix -webkit-hyphenate-character CSS property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
This change supports unprefixed hyphenate-character, not only -webkit-hyphenate-character.

According to the csswg discussion, https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/6887, hyphenate-character css property is stable enough to ship.

name: Unprefix CSS "grab" and "grabbing" Values for Cursor Property

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: These values change the mouse cursor to an open hand or closed hand to indicate that something can be grabbed or is currently grabbed. Prefixed versions of these properties have been supported since Chrome 1, with Windows support added in Chrome 22. With this change Chrome will support the standard, unprefixed versions of these values.

name: Unprefix CSS 'line-break' property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The CSS 'line-break' property specifies the strictness of line-breaking rules. The exact definition of the strictness depends on languages.

Our implementation relies on ICU (see doc link) which supports East Asian writing systems and Finnish.

name: Unprefix CSS Grid Layout gutter properties

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Rename gutter properties to remove "grid-" prefix:
* grid-gap => gap
* grid-row-gap => row-gap
* grid-column-gap => column-gap

Note that column-gap already exists and is used by css-multicol.

The parsing needs to be updated as now the default value is "normal".

The old (prefixed) properties names will be kept working as aliases.

name: Unprefixed 'appearance' CSS property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: This feature introduces 'appearance' CSS property, which is the unprefixed version of '-webkit-appearance'.

name: Unprefixed CSS Animations

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: CSS Animations without the -webkit- prefix.

name: Unprefixed CSS Clipping Paths

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The CSS Clipping Path (CSS Masking specification) property without the "webkit" prefix.

name: Unprefixed CSS Filters

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: CSS Filters without the -webkit- prefix.

name: Unprefixed CSS Transforms

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Enables changing the position of content in 3D space without disrupting the document's normal flow.

name: Unprefixed CSS Writing Modes with syntax updates

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
CSS Writing Modes Level 3 without "webkit" prefix, along with syntax updates to the most recent CR.

As part of the work, a non-standard value "horizontal-bt" is removed from -webkit-writing-mode.

name: Unprefixed CSS user-select

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The user-select property enables authors to specify which elements in the document can be selected by the user and how.
Chrome has supported only prefixed version: -webkit-user-select.

name: Unprefixed Fullscreen API

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The fullscreen API has features for entering, and exiting fullscreen mode as well as event handlers for monitoring such changes. A prefixed version of the API has been supported since Chrome 15. This update adds an unprefixed version of the API.

name: Unprefixed Resource Timing API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Resource Timing extensions to the Performance interface without the "webkit" prefix.

name: Unprefixed Web Audio API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: A high-level JavaScript API for processing and synthesizing audio in web applications

view.notes: Shipped prefixed '-webkit-ruby-position'
Multiple video vendors asked this feature.

name: Unprefixed ruby-position CSS property

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The 'ruby-position' CSS property controls the position of ruby annotation.  It's the unprefixed version of the '-webkit-ruby-position' property. This property has three possible keywords: 'over', 'under', and 'inter-character'. For now, only the first two are being implemented. This change creates feature parity with Firefox.

name: Unprefixed text-emphasis properties

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: This feature introduces 'text-emphasis', 'text-emphasis-color', 'text-emphasis-position', and 'text-emphasis-style' CSS properties.  They are unprefixed versions of '-webkit-text-emphasis', '-webkit-text-emphasis-color', '-webkit-text-emphasis-position', and '-webkit-text-emphasis-style'.

name: Unscopables (ES6)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Unscopables allows properties to be hidden to with statement lookup rules. This is important for adding new properties to existing objects both in JavaScript and in DOM.

name: Update <textarea maxlength/minlength> behavior for linebreaks

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The specification was updated by https://github.com/whatwg/html/commit/163703186794c21daa92cc2718218afa44f26071.

Before the change, maxlength/minlength limits |value| length, not |API value| length.  In <textarea>, a single linebreak is represented as CR LF in |value|, and LF in |API value|.

Firefox and Edge incorrectly applied to |API value|, and WebKit and Blink correctly applied to |value|.  But the specification followed Firefox and Edge.

name: Update User-Agent Client Hints GREASE implementation

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: We seek to align our implementation of GREASE in User Agent Client Hints with the current spec, which includes additional GREASE characters beyond the current semicolon and space, and which recommends varying the arbitrary version. This is to help prevent bad assumptions from being built on top of User-Agent strings.

name: Update behavior of CSS Grid Layout percentage row tracks and gutters

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: This updates the behavior of percentage row tracks and gutters in grid containers with indefinite heights. Previously, these were behaving similarly to percentage heights in regular blocks, but the CSS WG has resolved to make them behave the same as for columns, making them symmetric. Percentages are now ignored when computing intrinsic height and resolved afterwards against that height. That way both column and row axes will have symmetric behavior to resolve percentages tracks and gutters.

name: Update colSpan max value to 1000

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Update colSpan max value from 8190 to 1000 as per spec change.

https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-tdth-colspan
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-col-span
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#dom-colgroup-span

name: Update fallback content's behavior for ImageInputType and HTMLImageElement

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Previously, there have been inconsistencies on the implementation of fallback content and its treatment as a replaced element for ImageInputType and HTMLImageElement. This led to interoperable issues between implementors. Examples: Please see, https://github.com/yuzhe-han/images-fallback-content-1094763, for visual comparison.

name: Update ol.start default value as 1

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
As per the spec,
"The start IDL attribute must reflect the content attribute of the same name, with a default value of 1.

This means that the start IDL attribute does not necessarily match the list's starting value, in cases where the start content attribute is omitted and the reversed content attribute is specified."

name: Update the behavior of the "disabled" attribute for HTMLLinkElement

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Previously, Chromium had intermittent behavior with respect to the "disabled" attribute:
 - <link id=foo rel="stylesheet" disabled> would not show up in document.styleSheets.
 - foo.disabled=false; foo.disabled=true; would cause it to appear (and remain) in document.styleSheets.
 - <link rel="alternate stylesheet"> cannot be enabled, except by disabling and re-enabling it.
 - When disabled, link.ownerNode was not null 

The above issues are being resolved.

name: Updated dialog initial focus algorithm

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Some changes are being made to which element is selected to get focus when a dialog element is opened:
1. Make the dialog focusing steps look at keyboard focusable elements instead of any focusable element.
2. Make the dialog element itself get focus if it has the autofocus attribute set.
3. Make the dialog element itself get focus as a fallback instead of focus being "reset" to the body element.

name: Upgrade insecure requests

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: We encourage authors to transition their sites and applications away from insecure transport, and onto encrypted and authenticated connections, but mixed content checking causes headaches. This feature allows authors to ask the user agent to transparently upgrade HTTP resources to HTTPS to ease the migration burden.

view.notes: Has shipped :focus-visible in version 85, which uses :-moz-focusring in the UA style sheet. But the implementation has changed now to use :focus-visible.

WebKit doesn't have an implementation of :focus-visible yet (I'm currently working on adding support for it). But it already uses something special in the UA style sheet :-webkit-direct-focus, due to a somehow related issue (see https://github.com/w3c/csswg-drafts/issues/5893), hopefully once :focus-visible is ready it could replace :-webkit-direct-focus in the UA style sheet.

Bug has 7 stars: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1162070
Another bug was reported 1 year ago about the very same issue: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1038823
This blog post explains the need of ":not(:focus-visible)" and mentions it as "less than elegant" solution: https://developer.paciellogroup.com/blog/2018/03/focus-visible-and-backwards-compatibility/
Also this other blog post talks about this problem too: https://css-tricks.com/the-focus-visible-trick/

name: Use :focus-visible in the default UA style sheet

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Change the Chromium default UA style sheet to use :focus-visible instead of :focus pseudo-class to paint the focus indicator (outline).

This will avoid that elements show a focus indicator (because they're focused and match :focus) while they don't match :focus-visible.

name: Use Non-Transitional IDNA Processing in URLs

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Enable IDNA 2008 in Non-Transitional Mode for URL processing, aligning Chrome's behavior with Firefox and Safari.
 
Chrome currently uses IDNA 2008 in Transitional Mode in URL processing. The main difference between Transitional and Non-Transitional Mode is the handling of four characters known as deviation characters: ß (LATIN SMALL LETTER SHARP S), ς (GREEK SMALL LETTER FINAL SIGMA), ZWJ (Zero width joiner) and ZWNJ (Zero width non-joiner).

In Transitional mode, deviation characters are handled the same as IDNA2003: ß is mapped to ss, ς is mapped to σ, and ZWJ and ZWNJ are deleted. In Non-Transitional mode, domains containing these characters are allowed in domain names without mapping, and thus can resolve to different IP addresses. For example, typing "faß.de" in Chrome and Firefox opens different sites today.

Enabling Non-Transitional IDNA in Chrome will allow deviation characters in domain names. Firefox and Safari already made this change in 2016 and continue to use Non-Transitional URL processing.

name: User Activation Query API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Some APIs cannot be used with a user activation (https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/interaction.html#activation). Examples include requestFullScreen(), autoplay, window.open(). This restriction is a powerful tool for preventing annoying behavior by web pages. Unfortunately, there is no way to determine if a user activation is active. The User Activation Query API adds this ability.

view.notes: Support and involvement in API development from multiple web developers and payment industry partners. Both Stripe and AirBnB have publicly stated that they have either completed or are in the process of prototyping/experimenting with SPC

name: User Activation Requirement for SPC Credential Enrollment

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: This intent is to add a user activation requirement for Secure Payment Confirmation (SPC) credential enrollment in a cross-origin iframe to help mitigate a privacy issue (see https://github.com/w3c/secure-payme for discussion of a potential identity tracking attack).

name: User Activation v2

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: User activation is the mechanism to maintain active-user-interaction state that limits use of "abusable" APIs (e.g. opening popups or vibrating). The web exposed behavior varies widely among major browsers. To unify the web, this feature defines a new user activation model that is simple enough for cross-browser implementation. The main changes introduced by this model are: (a) there is no concept of token passing, and (b) activation visibility changes from stack-scoped to frame-scoped.

name: User Timing API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Helps web developers measure the performance of their applications by giving them access to high precision timestamps.

name: User Timing L3

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
User Timing Level 3 extends the existing User Timing API to enable two new use cases:
1. Developers can pass custom timestamps to performance.measure() and performance.mark(), so as to conduct measurement across arbitrary timestamps. 
2. Developers can report arbitrary metadata with performance.mark() and performance.measure(), which provides rich data to analytics via a standardized API.

name: VP9

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: VP9 is an open and royalty free video compression standard.

name: VP9 software encoder/decoder in Chrome for WebRTC

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Include a VP9 video codec encoder and decoder in Chrome for use with WebRTC.

name: VTTCue

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The VTTCue interface, part of WebVTT. Previously the members of VTTCue were on the TextTrackCue interface and there was a TextTrackCue constructor, now the VTTCue constructor must be used instead.

view.notes: The standards position was already "worth implementing" and no a fast-paced effort to deliver COLRv1 including variations support to users is driven by Jonathan Kew. The high quality implementation can already be tested in FF Nightly.
See discussion in previous COLRv1 intent-to-ship. Since then, I would say their stance towards COLRv1 has changed from negative to "observing".
Google Fonts, Underware.nl and other type foundry partners are anticipating this feature.

name: Variable COLRv1

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: COLRv1 color vector fonts have been released in Chrome 98 https://developer.chrome.com/blog/colrv1-fonts/ but this initial release  supported only static functionality of the COLRv1 table. The COLRv1 specification defines integration with OpenType Variations which allows modifying font properties of gradients and transforms by means of changing variable axis parameters. This second step brings support for such variations to COLRv1.

name: Vibration API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: This specification defines an API that provides access to the vibration mechanism of the hosting device. Vibration is a form of tactile feedback. Note this feature is only available on Android.

view.notes:
Interest and developer experiments with the API:

https://twitter.com/jaffathecake/status/1524782819431555074?t=itU6B0wo6SbjomGiSKLmGQ&s=19

https://www.reddit.com/r/webdev/comments/uyoit1/i_played_around_with_chromes_new_shared_element/

https://twitter.com/OliverJAsh/status/1530261401016705026?t=CXqW2yiIMbH6bLfn8ImINw&s=19

https://css-tricks.com/spas-shared-element-transitions-and-re-evaluating-technology/

name: View Transitions API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
View Transitions is an API that enables the creation of polished transitions. Web developers only need minimal effort to make transitions look nice. They can choose to use some default animation properties, or they can customize their own transition effects to achieve a desired transition experience.

This is accomplished by leveraging user-agents’ ability to persist visual representations of rendered output (i.e. snapshots) and blend them with the live DOM state’s rendered output. The API also allows these animations to be customized via standard CSS animation properties.

view.notes: Likely to be neutral based on discussion in https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/79

name: Viewport-height client hint

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Currently, Responsive Image Client Hints provide a way for origins to obtain the viewport’s width. However, no such attribute exists for viewport height. We’ve observed that to optimize the loading of content that appears in viewport, it is essential for the origins to adapt HTML response based on viewport height.

name: Virtual viewport pinch-zoom

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Pinch to zoom will behave rationally with respect to position:fixed elements. position:fixed elements no longer stick to the visual viewport during a pinch-zoom.

view.notes:
Signals from webdevs: https://github.com/w3c/editing/issues/308
Signal from MS Office (https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/507#issuecomment-812766805)
Signal from Google docs (https://docs.google.com/document/d/1KtmXy9kGwADyP5x1tfLtGt8v86XetAiZwgcOTnDyTOY)
In the I2P thread few web devs also showed interest.
Here is a known bug: https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=856269

name: VirtualKeyboard API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The virtual keyboard is the on-screen keyboard used for input in scenarios where a hardware keyboard may not be available. 
The VirtualKeyboard interface has APIs to provide authors with more control over when the virtual keyboard is shown or hidden. It also fires events with the size of the virtual keyboard when it occludes content in the page.

name: WOFF 2.0 (improved font compression)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
WOFF 2.0 significantly improves font compression. We are seeing average gains of 24% with peaks above 50% in particular for the larger fonts such as those typically used by CJK languages (analysis ran on the whole Google Fonts corpus).


M33: switching to Brotli Compression Algorithm (instead of LZMA).
M36: enabled by default.

name: WakeLockSentinel.released Attribute

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The WakeLockSentinel object has a new attribute called `released` that indicates whether a sentinel has already been released. Its value is initially false, and it changes to true once a "release" event is dispatched.

name: WeakMap (ES6)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: WeakMaps are key/value maps in which keys are objects.

name: WeakSet (ES6)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: ES6 WeakSets are sets of arbitrary JavaScript objects, that hold on to their keys weakly

view.notes: Supported in Firefox 75
Supported on Safari 13.1 macOS 10.14.

name: Web Animations API

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Update the web animations JavaScript API to align with the specifications in https://drafts.csswg.org/web-animations-1/.

The Animation interface is extended to include support for promises, replaceable animations, and read-only access to the animation timeline.

The Animatable and DocumentOrShadowRoot interfaces are expanded to support getAnimations.

The KeyframeEffect interface is expanded to support compositing modes, getKeyframes, setKeyframes, and pseudoElement.

name: Web Animations JavaScript API [element.animate()]

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: A unified model for supporting animation and synchronization on the Web platform.

name: Web Animations JavaScript API [level 1 interop part 1]

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A unified model for supporting animation and synchronization on the Web platform. This feature covers bug and interop fixes to bring Chrome in line with the spec: Cancel events; Animation.id; pause() moves from idle to the paused state; deprecate dashed-names as keys in keyframes.

name: Web Animations JavaScript API [level 1 interop part 2]

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A unified model for supporting animation and synchronization on the Web platform. This feature covers bug and interop fixes to bring Chrome in line with the spec: lists of values in keyframes; remove dashed-names as keys in keyframes.

name: Web Animations Javascript API [playback control]

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A unified model for supporting animation and synchronization on the Web platform. This feature covers playback control of AnimationPlayer: play(), pause(), reverse(), finish(), currentTime, startTime, playbackRate and playState.

name: Web Application Manifest

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: This specification defines a JSON-based manifest, which provides developers with a centralized place to put metadata associated with a web application. This includes, but is not limited to, the web application's name, links to icons, as well as the preferred URL to open when the user launches the web application. The manifest also allows developers to declare a default orientation for their web application, as well as how the application is to be displayed by the user agent (e.g. in fullscreen).

name: Web Authentication API for Chrome

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The Credential Management API (Chrome 51 and later) defined a framework for retrieving credentials, including semantics for creating, getting, and storing them. It did this through two credential types: PasswordCredential and FederatedCredential. The Web Authentication API adds a third credential type, PublicKeyCredential, which allows web applications to  create and use strong, cryptographically attested, and application-scoped credentials to strongly authenticate users.

name: Web Authentication API: FIDO CTAP2 PIN support

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: The Web Authentication API (WebAuthn) lets web applications authenticate users via external authentication devices called security keys. This feature extends Chrome's implementation of WebAuthn to support local user authorization of security key operations via a user-defined PIN for keys that implement the FIDO CTAP2 protocol. Web sites using WebAuthn can request or require such authorization via the API's "user verification" mechanisms (https://www.w3.org/TR/webauthn/#user-verification).

name: Web Authentication API: Resident Keys

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Security keys are generally stateless save for a global signature counter. While it’s technically possible to implement a stateful security key, physical tokens generally encrypt their state in a credential ID that is stored on the server of the relying party.

Resident keys allow the security key to keep state and thus allow a username-less login experience by just proving a local PIN to the device. Developers can exercise this via the existing Webauthn standard.

name: Web Authentication getTransports

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
The W3C Web Authentication API[1] provides an official replacement for the internal extension that Chrome ships to implement the FIDO U2F API for security keys.

The getTransports call is part of the current level two draft[2] and provides transport (e.g. USB, NFC, etc) information without wedging it into the attestation certificate, which is the current practice.

[1] https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/
[2] https://github.com/w3c/webauthn/commit/11d549048ac5e462a4f9f44499032302adb29800

view.notes: Firefox participates in the WebAuthn working group and approved the PR adding this to the spec.
Safari has an implementation of WebAuthn in developer previews of Safari but hasn't commented publicly about iframe support.

name: Web Authenticator API: cross-origin iframe support

docs: None. WebAuthn actions will now be permitted when Feature Policy allows it.

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Adds support for web authentication calls from cross-origin iframes if enabled by a feature policy. This brings Chrome in line with the Web Authentication level two specification (https://w3c.github.io/webauthn/#sctn-iframe-guidance).

name: Web Bluetooth API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Allows web sites to communicate over GATT with nearby user-selected Bluetooth devices in a secure and privacy-preserving way.

Status in Chrome is more complicated than can be captured by this form. In Chrome 56, this shipped on Android, ChromeOS, and macOS. In Chrome 70 it is shipping on Windows 10. For earlier versions of Windows and Linux, it is still behind a flag (chrome://flags/#enable-experimental-web-platform-features).

view.notes: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=101034
This is the discussion for this feature in the Web Bluetooth specification repository.

name: Web Bluetooth Write With/Without Response

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Implements two APIs for writing to GATT characteristics that will allow an app to ignore a response from the device or to expect a response from the device.

The currently implemented writeValue() method will remain for backwards compatibility, but is discouraged.

view.notes: I haven't found anything mentioning getAvailability() specifically. However, Web Bluetooth in general does have support from developers.

name: Web Bluetooth getAvailability()

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: getAvailability() returns a promise that resolves with true if the user agent is running on a system that has a Bluetooth radio and false otherwise. The powered state of the Bluetooth radio does not influence the availability because applications can prompt users to turn on the radio using requestDevice(). The availabilitychanged event can be used to detect changes in the availability of the Bluetooth radio.

view.notes: unlikely to object to this specifically, but object to the overall Web Bluetooth API as a whole, hence doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.
unlikely to object to this specifically, but object to the overall Web Bluetooth API as a whole, hence doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.

name: Web Bluetooth manufacturer data filter

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Being able to filter based on manufacturer specific data (such as vendor ID and product ID) will enable e.g. manufacturer.example.com to configure/select only its own Bluetooth devices and present them to users, instead of showing unrelated Bluetooth devices in the browser picker.

name: Web Crypto API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: JavaScript bindings for cryptographic operations

view.notes: Webkit has a custom format implementation which isn't well documented.
Positive signal from Figma & Sketchup. Internal MS office products have shown interest in supporting this API.

name: Web Custom formats for Async Clipboard API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Web Custom formats let websites read and write arbitrary unsanitized payloads using a standardized web custom format, as well as read and write a limited subset of OS-specific formats (for supporting legacy apps).
The name of the clipboard format is mangled by the browser in a standardized way to indicate that the content is from the web, which allows native applications to opt-in to accepting the unsanitized content.

name: Web Locks API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This API allows scripts running in one tab to asynchronously acquire a lock, hold it while work is performed, then release it. While held, no other script in the origin can acquire the same lock. A lock represents some potentially shared resource, identified by a name chosen by the web app. For example, if a web app running in multiple tabs wants to ensure that only one tab is syncing to the network, each tab could try to acquire a "my_net_sync" lock, but only one tab will succeed.

name: Web MIDI API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Defines an API supporting the MIDI protocol, enabling web applications to enumerate and select MIDI input and output devices on the client system and send and receive MIDI messages.

name: Web NFC

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Web NFC aims to provide sites the ability to read and write to NFC tags when they are brought in close proximity to the user’s device (usually 5-10 cm, 2-4 inches). The current scope is limited to NDEF, a lightweight binary message format. Low-level I/O operations (e.g. ISO-DEP, NFC-A/B, NFC-F) and Host-based Card Emulation (HCE) are not supported within the current scope.

view.notes: [1] Both Gecko and Webkit are unlikely to object to this feature specifically, but object to the overall Web NFC API as a whole, hence doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.
[1] Both Gecko and Webkit are unlikely to object to this feature specifically, but object to the overall Web NFC API as a whole, hence doesn't make sense to bug them with specific questions on this.

name: Web NFC: NDEFReader makeReadOnly()

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The NDEFReader makeReadOnly() method allows web developers to make NFC tags permanently read-only with Web NFC.

view.notes: Removed in Safari 13.

name: Web SQL Database

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: API exposing an SQLite database

name: Web Serial API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The Serial API provides an interface for connecting to serial devices, either through a serial port on the user’s system or removable USB and Bluetooth devices that emulate a serial port. This API has been requested by the hardware developer community, especially developers building educational tools, as a companion to the WebUSB API because operating systems require applications to communicate with USB-based serial ports using their higher-level serial API rather than the low-level USB API.

view.notes: https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/27

name: Web Share API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Web Share is an API for sharing data (text, URLs, images) from the web to an app of the user's choosing.

view.notes: The ability to share images and files has been a consistent request.

name: Web Share API Level 2

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Web Share API Level 2 allows sharing of files from the web to an app of the user's choosing.

The API enables web developers to build share buttons that display the same system share dialog boxes used by native applications. Level 1 enabled system share dialogs; however only text and urls could previously be shared.

name: Web Share Target

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Web Share Target allows websites to receive shared data (text, URLs, images) and register to be choosable by the user as targets from sharing contexts, including (but not limited to) Web Share.

view.notes: Implementation issue: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1476515
Implementation issue: https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=194593

name: Web Share Target Level 2

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Installed web applications can now receive file shares, e.g. images. Using the manifest, the web application can declare which MIME types and/or file extensions it accepts.

Previously, mobile platforms allowed files to be shared to native applications, but not web applications.

name: Web Speech API (input)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Enables web developers to incorporate speech recognition into their web pages.

name: Web Speech API (synthesis)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Enables web developers to incorporate speech synthesis into their web pages. Uses whatever the platform provides for synthesis.

Coming in M71, synthesis will have a few small changes.
1. Exposing the following existing interfaces: SpeechSynthesis, SpeechSynthesisVoice, SpeechSynthesisEvent
2. Adding a constructor to SpeechSynthesisEvent
3. Adding and exposing a new interface, SpeechSynthesisErrorEvent.

name: Web Storage

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Refers to both localStorage and sessionStorage

name: Web Storage: Anonymous getter may return null

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Blink used to add an anonymous named property getter to the Storage interface (used by sessionStorage and localStorage) that behaved slightly differently from the getItem() method. The anonymous getter has been removed, and getItem() is now used behind the scenes instead. One visible consequence is that attempting to access a key that does not exist via the getter will return null instead of undefined.

name: Web Storage: Methods are now enumerable

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The methods belonging to the Storage IDL interface (available via sessionStorage and localStorage), such as getItem(), clear() and removeItem() are now enumerable as mandated by the HTML spec.

They are not returned by Object.keys(), but do appear in e.g. for-in loops.

name: Web USB sameObject behavior

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Make USBConfiguration, USBInterface, USBAlternateInterface, and USBEndpoint instances returned by the accessors on USBDevice === comparable.

name: Web notification inline replies

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This feature adds support for text actions on web notifications. It allows web developers to let users quickly input text in response to a notification, within the notification itself. This is expected to be particularly useful for chat apps.

name: Web payment manifests

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: For every payment method, there must be a corresponding JSON manifest file describing how that method participates in the web payments ecosystem.

name: Web/native app install banners

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Chrome 42 for Android will encourage users to add high quality sites they visit frequently to their home screen. In the future it will support the same for native apps.

This entry is for the visual aspect, not the API surface. The Manifest API surface is covered by https://www.chromestatus.com/features/4754986680451072. The event API surface is covered in https://www.chromestatus.com/features/6560913322672128

name: WebAssembly

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: WebAssembly, or wasm, is an efficient low-level programming language for in-browser client-side execution. It is designed to support C/C++ and similar low-level languages. Future versions may be enhanced to better support other languages. WebAssembly is intended to be small, fast to decode, fast to compile, and fast to execute.

view.notes: Shipped in version 78.

name: WebAssembly BigInt Integration

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allow WebAssembly to import and export WebAssembly function parameters of type i64 using BigInt.

name: WebAssembly Bulk Memory Operations

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds a memmove type opcode to WebAssembly and enhances existing data sections to support importable base.This allows better optimization of large memcpy/memmove operations. Data section improvement will make shared libraries work better, especially with threads.

name: WebAssembly Content Security Policy

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Enhancements to Content Security Policy to improve interoperability with WebAssembly.

name: WebAssembly Dynamic Tiering

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: With WebAssembly Dynamic Tiering, an heuristic decides which functions of a WebAssembly module get optimized, and when the optimization is triggered. This is an improvement to the existing eager optimization approach, where all functions get optimized immediately after baseline compilation is finished. WebAssembly Dynamic Tiering reduces the resource consumption of the optimizing compiler, and prevents the compiler from competing with the web application for resources.

view.notes: This feature is one of the last bits missing to port legacy c++ apps to the web

name: WebAssembly Exception Handling

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: This feature is adding exception support to WebAssembly. Exception handling allows code to break control flow when an exception is thrown. The exception can be any exception known by the WebAssembly module, or it may be an unknown exception that was thrown by a called imported function.

name: WebAssembly Import/Export Mutable Globals

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Allows WebAssembly modules to import and export mutable globals. This building block will allow efficient passing of values like shadow stacks pointers between dynamically liked modules (especially in the multi-threaded case).

name: WebAssembly Multi-Value

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Add support for WebAssembly functions and blocks that return more than one value.

name: WebAssembly Non-trapping Conversion

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds opcodes to WebAssembly to support non-trapping float-to-integer conversion to improve the ergonomics of the bytecode format.

name: WebAssembly PostMessage

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Extends WebAssembly to support PostMessage of WebAssembly.Module objects to Web Workers. To clarify, this is scoped to just Web Workers (same process, different thread), and not extended to cross-process scenarios (such as cross-origin postMessage, or shared web workers).

name: WebAssembly Reference Types

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Allow WebAssembly modules to hold references to JS/DOM objects, passing them as arguments, storing them in locals and globals, and storing them in WebAssembly.Table objects.

name: WebAssembly SIMD

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
WebAssembly SIMD will expose hardware SIMD instructions to WebAssembly applications in a platform-independent way. The SIMD proposal introduces a new 128-bit value type that can be used to represent different types of packed data, and several vector operations that operate on packed data. 

SIMD can boost performance by exploiting data level parallelism and is also useful when compiling native code to WebAssembly

name: WebAssembly Sign Extension Opcodes

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add sign extension opcodes to WebAssembly. This makes some code sequences shorter and allows us to provide only zero extended versions of atomic opcodes for threads.

name: WebAssembly Tail Call

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add an explicit tail call and indirect tail call opcodes to WebAssembly.

name: WebAssembly Worker Based Threads

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The WebAssembly Threads feature allows multiple WebAssembly instances in separate Web Workers to share a single WebAssembly.Memory object.

As with SharedArrayBuffers in JavaScript, this allows very fast communication between the Workers. This can be used to offload computation to another thread to keep the main thread and its UI responsive.

view.notes: Browser vendor is part of the WebAssembly community group and engaged within the spec discussion. Their intent is to implement it as well
Browser vendor is part of the WebAssembly community group and engaged within the spec discussion

name: WebAssembly cross-origin module sharing

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
WebAssembly module sharing between cross-origin but same-site environments will be deprecated to allow agent clusters to be scoped to origins long term. This is a WebAssembly spec change, which has an impact on the platform as well.

Therefore this deprecation is the first step to deprecate document.domain

name: WebAssembly trap-based bounds checking

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Instead of doing explicit bounds checks, this feature surrounds WebAssembly memories with guard regions. Accesses to these guard regions will trap, and the crash handler will recover from the crash by throwing a JavaScript exception.

name: WebAudio:  Add IIRFilterNode

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add a new node, IIRFilterNode, that implements a general IIR filter.  The coefficients are fixed at creation and not changeable with no automation functions allowed.

name: WebAudio:  AudioParams include min/max attributes to specify the nominal range

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: All AudioParams have a readonly min and max attribute to specify the minimum and maximum value the AudioParam can have.  The value is clamped to lie in this range.  This allows easy introspection for the developer to determine the valid ranges for a parameter.

name: WebAudio: Add AudioContext.getOutputTimestamp() method

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The AudioContext.getOutputTimestamp() method helps to synchronize DOM time and AudioContext time values. It is used to estimate DOMHighResTimeStamp value of the audio output stream position for the given AudioContext.currentTime value, or do the opposite: estimate  AudioContext.currentTime value of the audio output stream position for the given DOMHighResTimeStamp value.

name: WebAudio: Add AudioScheduledSourceNode base class for source nodes

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Add AudioScheduledSourceNode as a base class of AudioBufferSourceNode, OscillatorNode, and ConstantSourceNode.

This is a small change to capture the common features of the source nodes into a base class.

name: WebAudio: Add Automation Support to PannerNode and AudioListener

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Automation methods for the position and orientation coordinates of PannerNode and the position, up, and forward vectors of the AudioListener are added.  This allows smooth changes in the coordinates via AudioParam methods.

This effectively undeprecates the PannerNode and AudioListener.  The old methods such as setPosition, setOrientation, etc., are retained, but deprecated because they have obvious equivalents with just setting the individual coordinate values.

name: WebAudio: Add BaseAudioContext

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Implement BaseAudioContext according to the spec. This introduces a trivial but user-visible change: querying `AudioContext.prototype.hasOwnProperty(functionName)` will fail. See the comment to see how to fix the potential issue.

name: WebAudio: Add ConstantSourceNode

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add a new ConstantSourceNode that produces a constant output mixed with an AudioParam.  This node serves as a constant source and also as a "constructible AudioParam"

name: WebAudio: Add User Selectable Automation Rate for AudioParams

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Gives each AudioParam a new attribute, automationRate that allows the user to select whether the AudioParam is either "a-rate" or "k-rate".  Most but not all AudioParams allow changing the rate (as given in the spec).

For example, BiquadFilterNode with default "a-rate" automation is very expensive to compute due to the complex relationship between the parameters and the filter coefficients.  If this fast automation is not needed (the most typical case), the parameters can be set to "k-rate".

name: WebAudio: Add buffering/latency hint via latencyHint

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Currently, WebAudio will use the lowest latency possible for the audio device for the best interactive behavior.  However, for some use-cases such as media playback, this causes unnecessary power and/or CPU utilization.

The latencyHint is a hint from the developer that such a latency is not required. The latencyHint is either an AudioContextLatencyCategory value or a double specifying the desired numeric latency.  This is a hint to Chrome.

name: WebAudio: Allow developers to close an AudioContext explicitly

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: An AudioContext can now be explicitly closed, thereby releasing any hardware resources associated with the AudioContext. Without this, developers had to depend on garbage collection of the AudioContext to release hardware resources.

name: WebAudio: Allow disabling normalization in PeriodicWave

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: createPeriodicWave() takes an optional third parameter that allows enabling or disabling normalization of the waveform that would be produced by a PeriodicWave.  The default is to enable normalization, which was the previous behavior.

name: WebAudio: AudioBuffer constructor only takes one argument

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Currently the AudioBuffer constructor takes two arguments: the context, and the AudioBufferOptions.  The context argument is removed so that only AudioBufferOptions is required.  In addition the sampleRate member of AudioBufferOptions is now required.

name: WebAudio: AudioBuffer copyFromChannel and copyToChannel

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Support the copyFromChannel and copyToChannel methods on a WebAudio AudioBuffer

name: WebAudio: AudioBufferSourceNode.detune

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add ‘detune’ feature to AudioBufferSourceNode for the sample-accurate pitch control of sample playback.

name: WebAudio: AudioNode constructors

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add constructor for WebAudio AudioNodes. Instead of saying "context.createFoo()", you can now say "new FooNode(context, optionalOptions)", roughly.

name: WebAudio: AudioParam cancelAndHoldAtTime

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: cancelAndHoldAtTime cancels future AudioParam events and holds the value of the AudioParam at the value at the scheduled time.

name: WebAudio: AudioParam setter is equivalent to setValueAtTime

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
When setting the value of an AudioParam via the value setter, the value is updated exactly as if setValueAtTime(newValue, context.currentTime).

This includes throwing errors that weren't previously thrown and changing the AudioParam timeline

name: WebAudio: Biquad filters run at a-rate

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Automations for the BiquadFilter node will run at a-rate (updated every frame) instead of the current k-rate (updated every rendering quantum of 128 frames)

name: WebAudio: ChannelMergerNode Static Routing

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This is to change the behavior of ChannelMergerNode when the input changes dynamically. There have been  critical issues with the previous implementation. (See related issues for the detail)

To address these issues, a new proposal for the ChannelMergerNode was made. The proposal effectively makes the channel order in the merger node static after the instantiation.

name: WebAudio: ChannelSplitterNode channelCount and channelCountMode are constant

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The channelCount and channelCountMode attributes for a ChannelSplitterNode are fixed to the number of outputs and "explicit", respectively.

They cannot be changed.

view.notes: Issue was filed by Mozilla engineer with agreement from another Mozilla engineer.

name: WebAudio: ConvolverNode.channelCount and channelCountMode

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: For a ConvolverNode, the channelCount can now be set to 1 or 2.  The channelCountMode can be "explicit" or "clamped-max".  Previously, a channelCount of 1 was not allowed and neither was a mode of "explicit".

name: WebAudio: DynamicsCompressor.reduction is a float not AudioParam

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Chrome implements the reduction attribute for a DynamicsCompressorNode as an AudioParam.  The WebAudio spec says it should be a readonly float.

Change Chrome to implement the specification.

name: WebAudio: Event Constructors

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allow WebAudio-specific events to be constructed. Specifically, OfflineAudioCompletionEvent and AudioProcessEvent can be constructed.

name: WebAudio: MediaElement and MediaStream nodes defined only for AudioContext

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Chrome historically allowed creation of MediaElementAudioSourceNode's, MediaStreamAudioSourceNode's, and MediaStreamAudioDestinationNode's using an OfflineAudioContext.  This does not comply with the spec; these nodes should only be available for an AudioContext.  The behavior with an OfflineAudioContext is not well-defined and contrary to the real-time nature of the nodes themselves.

Thus, only allow these nodes to be constructed for an AudioContext.

view.notes: Output count is 0 in 60.6.1esr.  Probably much earlier.

name: WebAudio: MediaStreamAudioDestinationNode has no outputs

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: According to the specification, the MediaStreamAudioDestinationNode in WebAudio should have no outputs. Chrome's implementation has a single output which will be removed.

name: WebAudio: New lowpass and highpass BiquadFilter implementation

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The existing lowpass and highpass BiquadFilter implementation has a defect where valid filters cannot be represented.  To fix this, the filter formulas were updated.  However, the new formulas will cause a change in the output of the filters.

name: WebAudio: OfflineAudioContext constructor with dictionary

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The constructor for an OfflineAudioContext now accepts a dictionary argument to specify the options needed to construct the context.  This is an addition to the existing constructor that takes three arguments.

name: WebAudio: OfflineAudioContext.length attribute

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add a length attribute to an OfflineAudioContext that indicates the length (in frames) that the offline context will render.

name: WebAudio: OfflineAudioContext.startRendering() returns a promise

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The startRendering() method for an OfflineAudioContext now returns a promise that is resolved with the rendered audio when rendering is done.

name: WebAudio: OfflineAudioContext.suspend() and resume()

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds suspend() and resume() feature in OfflineAudioContext to support the synchronous graph manipulation with the render block precision (k-rate) in the non-realtime audio rendering.

view.notes: Linked to the Firefox commit that has the correct IDL for this feature.

name: WebAudio: OscillatorOptions.periodicWave is not nullable

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
It is no longer possible to set the periodicWave member of OscillatorOptions to null.

The WebAudio spec doesn't allow this, so we're aligning Chrome with the spec and also Firefox, which has implemented this correctly for 4 years.

name: WebAudio: PannerNode default behavior

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The HRTF panner uses significant memory for the responses and requires a fair amount of processing to implement. For low-end mobile devices, this can be an issue. Since the default panner model is HRTF, the creation of the panner can cause the responses to be loaded.

The default has been changed to equalpower, which doesn't consume significant memory and is much less intensive in processing power.

name: WebAudio: PannerNode.rolloffFactor clamps to nominal range.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The PannerNode.rolloffFactor clamps to the nominal range which depends on the distance model being used.

name: WebAudio: Refine BiquadFilterNode AudioParam limits

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The WebAudio spec has updated the limits for the frequency, detune, and gain AudioParam attributes for a BiquadFilterNode.  Previously these allowed any floating-point value.

name: WebAudio: Remove Doppler API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Remove the deprecated Doppler API.  This includes removing speedOfSound, dopplerFactor, and setVelocity from the WebAudio API. This was removed from the WebAudio spec quite a while ago. The actual effect was removed a while ago, but the API remained.  The API is being removed now.

name: WebAudio: Remove dezippering

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Historically, Chrome implemented dezippering such that when the value setter of an AudioParam was used, the value was not changed instantaneously.  Instead, an exponential approach equivalent to setTargetValueAtTime was done.  The actual time constant used was never specified and depended on the AudioParam.

With the spec change in https://github.com/WebAudio/web-audio-api/pull/393, (Sep 2015), all dezippering was removed from the spec.

Dezippering will be removed from Chrome.

name: WebAudio: Remove prefixed AudioContext and OfflineAudioContext

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Support for webkitAudioContext and webkitOfflineAudioContext is removed in favor of AudioContext and OfflineAudioContext.  Currently warnings are produced, but upon removal, the prefixed versions will no longer exist.

name: WebAudio: Selective Disconnection on AudioNode.disconnect()

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Currently AudioNode.disconnect() disconnects all existing connections from output(s) of the AudioNode. This is to support disconnecting only one connection.

There have been numerous requests to support selective disconnection with disconnect() method and Audio WG agreed to change the spec to accommodate the feature request. With this change, it is possible to disconnect a signal path out of multiple connections to AudioNode input or AudioParam.

name: WebAudio: StereoPannerNode

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
StereoPannerNode is a audio processing node which positions an incoming audio stream in a stereo image using robust equal-power panning algorithm and sample-accurate automation.

Web Audio API specification has been updated to include a new audio node dedicated to equal-power stereo panning.

name: WebAudio: Support chaining on AudioNode.connect() and AudioParam automation methods

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This is to support ‘method chaining’ on AudioNode.connect() and the automation methods of AudioParam object. The current implementation does not return anything when these methods get executed. It improves the control flow and the readability of Web Audio JS code.

name: WebAudio: close() removed from OfflineAudioContext

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The close() method is no longer defined for an OfflineAudioContext. It only threw an error anyway, so it wasn't useful.  It's now only defined for an AudioContext.

name: WebAudio: decodeAudioData detaches ArrayBuffer

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
According to the spec, decodeAudioData detaches the given ArrayBuffer before decoding.  This means that the ArrayBuffer no longer has any contents and can't be reused or examined.

If it's important to keep the data, user ArrayBuffer.slice(0) to make a copy for decodeAudioData.

name: WebAudio: decodeAudioData returns a Promise

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: AudioContext.decodeAudioData returns a Promise<AudioBuffer> that is resolved when decoding the audio data is finished.  This is in addition to the existing callbacks, which are now optional.

name: WebAudio: suspend/resume

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Supports suspending and resuming an AudioContext to allow applications to pause the audio device when needed.  This reduces CPU usage and power consumption when audio is suspended.

name: WebAuthentication API: ResidentKeyRequirement and credProps extension

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds support for the AuthenticatorSelectionCriteria.residentKey property to specify during Web Authentication API (WebAuthn) credential registration whether a client-side discoverable credential should be created. Also adds support for the WebAuthn "credProps" extension, which indicates to the Relying Party whether a created credential is client-side discoverable.

view.notes: (J.C. reviewed spec PR.)

name: WebAuthn getPublicKey[Algorithm]() and getAuthenticatorData()

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Adds two accessors from the Web Authentication Level 2 spec that save sites from parsing Concise Binary Object Representation (CBOR) and CBOR Object Signing and Encryption (COSE) in order to use security keys.

name: WebAuthn minPinLength extension

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Expose the CTAP 2.1 minPinLength extension via WebAuthn.

This extension allows sites that have been preconfigured on a security key to learn the configured minimum PIN length for the authenticator. See https://fidoalliance.org/specs/fido-v2.1-ps-20210615/fido-client-to-authenticator-protocol-v2.1-ps-20210615.html#sctn-minpinlength-extension

view.notes: co-editing the spec (Paul Adenot)

"We have some concerns about WebCodecs, but don’t think we’ve stated a public position on it. Concerns about fingerprinting and design of the API, but I don’t think it’s fair to say “negative”. "

- Myles Maxfield

Wikipedia: https://discourse.wicg.io/t/webcodecs-proposal/3662/9 
Twitch: https://discourse.wicg.io/t/webcodecs-proposal/3662/12
Sony: https://discourse.wicg.io/t/webcodecs-proposal/3662/13

name: WebCodecs

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Provides efficient, low-level access to built-in (software and hardware) media encoders and decoders.

view.notes: Firefox is helping co-edit spec (Paul Adenot)
Edge: Positive, co-editing the spec (Bernard Aboba)

Expressed mixed interest/concerns.
https://lists.webkit.org/pipermail/webkit-dev/2020-May/031191.html
https://lists.webkit.org/pipermail/webkit-dev/2021-February/031691.html
See blurbs from OT participants at the bottom of the I2S.

name: WebCodecs dequeue event

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
This feature tracks adding a single event named "dequeue" to the audio and video encoder and decoder interfaces (e.g. AudioDecoder.ondequeue).

Authors may initially queue up encoding or decoding work by calling encode() or decode() respectively. The new "dequeue" event is fired to indicate when the underlying codec has ingested some/all of the queued work. The decrease in the queue size is already reflected by a lower value of encoder.encodeQueueSize and decoder.decodeQueueSize attributes. The new event eliminates the need for authors to setTimeout() poll to determine when the queue has decreased (i.e. when they should queue up more work).

See mentions of "dequeue" in the WebCodecs specification
https://w3c.github.io/webcodecs/#audiodecoder-event-summary

name: WebGL  (Canvas 3D)

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: 3D rendering via the <canvas> element.

name: WebGL 2

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: OpenGL ES 3.0 level rendering capabilities via the <canvas> element.

view.notes: Developed in close collaboration with Mozilla, spec changes reviewed by Mozilla.
Discussed in ColorWeb CG with Safari

name: WebGL canvas color management

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Implementation of WebGL color management API

WebGL allows specification of
- the color space that its drawing buffer is
- the color space that content should be converted to when importing as a texture

This feature is to update our implementation to include this functionality.

Prior to this feature, both of these defaulted to sRGB. Now they can also use "display-p3".

name: WebGLContextEvent on Web Workers

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The WebGLContextEvent type has been defined in Khronos' WebGL specification for a number of years, but it was not noticed until recently that in Blink, this type is not exposed on web workers. (Most applications simply add an event listener for the type, and do not look for its prototype in the global scope.)

This is a simple fix to Blink's Web IDL for WebGLContextEvent, but is a web exposed change.

view.notes: WebHID is mentioned under Anti Fingerprinting as an example of "features we have decided to not yet implement due to fingerprinting, security, and other concerns, and where we do not yet see a path to resolving those concerns"

USB headset vendors want to use WebHID to improve integration of call control features in web-based softphone applications (answer/reject/end call, microphone mute, redial, etc):
https://developer.jabra.com/site/global/sdks/web/documentation/index.gsp

Hobbyists are using WebHID to control niche devices like Razer Kraken Kitty:
https://twitter.com/sarahemm/status/1314006489510666241

name: WebHID (Human Interface Device)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status
