maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Correctly implement window.NodeFilter.  It should not have .prototype, and NodeIterator.filter and TreeWalker.filter should not wrap JavaScript objects.

name: Remove: document.createEvent('WebKitAnimationEvent')

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Remove non-standard 'WebKitAnimationEvent' support of document.createEvent().

name: Rendering FTP resources

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: FTP is a non-securable legacy protocol. When even the linux kernel is migrating off of it (https://www.kernel.org/shutting-down-ftp-services.html), it's really time to move on. One step toward deprecation and removal is to deprecate rendering resources from FTP servers and instead download them. We'll still generate directory listings, but any non-directory listing could be downloaded rather than rendered in the browser.

name: SVG (1.1) Fonts

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Use the SVG based font format (that non WebKit based browsers never implemented) as a @font-face web font.

name: SVG hasExtension() methods

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The hasExtension() methods have been removed in SVG2. As implemented in Blink they always returned false and were thus of no use.

name: SVGCursorElement

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The <cursor> element. Can be referenced from the 'cursor' property to provide a use-defined cursor image.

name: SVGElement.offset(Parent|Top|Left|Width|Height)

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: These attributes should only be supported on HTMLElement, but have been supported on all Elements in WebKit and Blink. getBoundingClientRect() can typically be used as a replacement.

name: SVGPathSeg interfaces

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The SVGPathSeg interfaces were part of SVG 1.1, but have been removed.

A polyfill is available at https://github.com/progers/pathseg

name: SVGSVGElement.pixelUnitToMillimeterX and friends

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
These were in SVG 1.1 put have been removed:
http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG11/struct.html#InterfaceSVGSVGElement
http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG2/struct.html#InterfaceSVGSVGElement

These properties all return the constant 0.2645833194255829 on all platforms, so they don't do what their names suggest.

name: Scoped Styles

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Boolean attribute for the <style> element (<style scoped>). When present, its styles only apply to the parent element.

name: Shadow DOM v0

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Shadow DOM v0 is deprecated at M70, and removed in M80. All code has been deleted as of M89.

Intent to Deprecate: https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/d/msg/blink-dev/h-JwMiPUnuU/sl79aLoLBQAJ

Shadow DOM v0 was an experimental technology, never implemented in any other browser. The spec is superseded by Shadow DOM v1, which is widely supported.

Note that the /deep/ combinator, which was changed to a no-op in M63, has been completely removed in M89.

name: Shadow-Piercing descendant combinator, '/deep/'

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The /deep/ combinator was a part of Shadow DOM v0, which has been deprecated and removed. Starting in M63, the /deep/ combinator was treated as a no-op, equivalent to a space " " combinator. As the code for all of Shadow DOM v0 was removed completely in M89, /deep/ will now throw exceptions in some JS operations, such as querySelectorAll. Simply replace it with " " to get pre-M89 behavior back.

name: SharedWorker: Remove workerStart

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: SharedWorker.workerStart has been deprecated for a while in the spec, and is not supported by other major browsers.

name: Stop Trusting SHA-1 Certificates

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Protect Chrome users from attackers who might use the broken SHA-1 hash algorithm to obtain counterfeit website authentication certificates.

name: Support for commonName matching in Certificates

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
RFC 2818 describes two methods to match a domain name against a certificate - using the available names within the subjectAlternativeName extension, or, in the absence of a SAN extension, falling back to the commonName.

The fallback to the commonName was deprecated in RFC 2818 (published in 2000), but support still remains in a number of TLS clients, often incorrectly.

name: TLS 1.0 and TLS 1.1

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
This removal has been delayed in Stable until Chrome 84.

TLS 1.0 and 1.1 were deprecated in Chrome 72 with a planned removal in Chrome 81 (in early 2020). Other browsers are also removing support for TLS 1.0 and 1.1 at this time. Previously, we showed a deprecation warning in DevTools. In M-79, Chrome marked affected sites as "Not Secure". In M-84, Chrome will show a full page interstitial warning on sites that do not support TLS 1.2 or higher. In M-98, the error will no longer be bypassable.

name: TLS 1.3 downgrade hardening bypass

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: TLS 1.3 includes a backwards-compatible hardening measure to strengthen downgrade protections. However, when we shipped TLS 1.3 last year, we had to partially disable this measure due to incompatibilities with some non-compliant TLS-terminating proxies. Chrome currently implements the hardening measure for certificates which chain up to known roots, but allows a bypass for certificates chaining up to unknown roots. We intend to enable it for all connections.

name: TextEncoder API: drop support for legacy encodings

docs: (Docs still refer to the utfLabel parameter, which is no longer supported.)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The TextEncoder API never supported legacy encodings (such as 'shift_jis', 'windows-1252', etc) except for two UTF-16 variants ('utf-16', 'utf-16be'). Usage was minimal and support was removed from the spec. The TextEncoder constructor will no longer take an argument (if one is passed it is ignored, as is the standard for DOM APIs), and will always encode to "the encoding" (utf-8).

name: TextTrackList and TextTrackCueList item methods

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Per spec the TextTrackList and TextTrackCueList have anonymous indexed getters, but no item method:
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#texttracklist
https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#texttrackcuelist

name: The "basic-card" method of PaymentRequest API

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Deprecate the "basic-card" payment method from PaymentRequest API.

name: Token Binding

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Token binding allows servers to cryptographically bind bearer tokens (such as cookies) to the TLS layer, to prevent attacks where an attacker exports a bearer token from the user's machine to present to a web service and impersonate the user.

name: Treat '#' as ending data URI body content

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: By spec, '#' characters in data URIs should not be treated as part of the URI body, and should instead only mark the start of the URI fragment component. Historically Chrome has not adhered to the spec, instead treating '#' characters as both fragment-starters and part of the body.

name: User gesture for touch scrolling

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
No longer allow opening pop-ups (and other sensitive operations) to occur during input events which represent a touch scroll.  In particular, touchstart and touchmove listeners now never have a user gesture.  touchend listeners do have a user gesture unless the user was scrolling / pinching.

Builds on https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5649871251963904.

name: VTTRegion-related bits of TextTrack

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The interface elements regions, addRegion() and removeRegion() have been removed from the WebVTT spec and will be removed from Chrome. The VTTCue.region property was added and the VTTRegion interface was updated to match a late version of the specification.

name: WEBGL_compressed_texture_atc

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
This extension provided the AMD_compressed_ATC_texture formats to the web.
Hardware support has dwindled to near-zero, so the extension has been deprecated/rejected by the WebGL Working Group.

Support for this extension has always been small (as it is hardware-dependent), so no existing applications should be relying on its presence.

name: Web MIDI MIDIMessageEvent.receivedTime deprecation

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Deprecate receivedTime property from MIDIMessageEvent.

This is because the attribute was introduced to represent a high-resolution timestamp for real-time MIDI processing, but DOM Event started using hi-resolution monotonic time instead of epoch time for Event.timeStamp that can cover our use-case too.

name: WebAudio: Disallow setting AudioBufferSourceNode.buffer more than once

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Setting AudioBufferSourceNode.buffer again after it has already been set to a non-null buffer is no longer allowed and will generate an exception.

This feature was deprecated and is now being removed

name: WebAudio: Remove AudioSourceNode interface

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Remove the AudioSourceNode interface.  This interface is not part of the WebAudio specification, is not constructible, and has no attributes so it basically has no user-accessible functionality.

name: XMLHttpRequestProgressEvent (position and totalSize)

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: The XMLHttpRequestProgressEvent interface will be removed, together with the attributes position and totalSize. Instead the ProgressEvent interface will be used, and the attributes loaded and total should be used instead.

view.notes: Never had a XSS Filter
Removed XSS Auditor in Fall 2021
Web developers have complaints about the functionality of the XSS Auditor causing site-breaking "false positives."

name: XSS Auditor

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Remove the XSS Auditor from Chrome.

name: [WebRTC] Deprecate and Remove mediaConstraint's googIPv6

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: "googIPv6: false" can be used (example: new RTCPeerConnection({}, {mandatory:{googIPv6:false}});) to disable IPv6 support in WebRTC. IPv6 has been enabled by default for many years and we should not be able to disable it. Remove this non-standard API.

name: document.origin

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The document.origin property will be deprecated and removed in Chromium, and then likely also removed from the DOM Standard. This property was only ever implemented in Chromium and WebKit. It is redundant with self.origin which can be used in both window and worker contexts and has wider support.

name: macOS: rounded borders for buttons in User-Agent stylesheet

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Only for macOS.

The default stylesheet for <button>, <input type=button>, <input type=reset>, <input type=submit>, a button in <input type=file> was changed in order to match OS-native buttons. 

Background-color, border, border-radius, and padding were changed.

name: overflow: -webkit-paged-x , overflow: -webkit-paged-y

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
These are old webkit-specific properties that allowed developers to fragment content over columns inside a scrollable region.

See: https://bl.ocks.org/grorg/99eb053b432070b05d1e29759d81458f

Practically speaking this isn't used. Most developers use it accidentally, and typically when it is used this property to forces a new formatting context similar to setting "overflow: hidden".

name: overflowchanged event

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: The overflowchanged event and the OverflowEvent interface have been removed.

name: registerProtocolHandler from non-secure contexts

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: HTML's registerProtocolHandler() gives a webpage a mechanism to register itself to handle a protocol after a user consents. For example, a web-based email application could register to handle the mailto: scheme. A corresponding unregisterProtocolHandler() API allows a site to abandon its protocol-handling registration.

name: showModalDialog

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The global showModalDialog() method displays a modal dialog box containing a specified HTML document. This feature has an incredibly high cost in terms of code complexity since it requires us to run an event loop on top of an arbitrary JavaScript stack.  It also complicates the web platform by making task dispatch reentrant and hard to reason about.

In Chrome 37 it was disabled and in Chrome 43 it is removed.

name: webkit-prefixed IndexedDB global aliases

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The IndexedDB entry point and global constructors were exposed with `webkit` prefixes as was common circa Chrome 11:

webkitIndexedDB (main entry point)
webkitIDBKeyRange (non-callable global constructor, but has useful static methods)
webkitIDBCursor webkitIDBDatabase webkitIDBFactory webkitIDBIndex  webkitIDBObjectStore webkitIDBRequest webkitIDBTransaction (non-callable global constructors)

The non-prefixed API shipped in M24 and the prefixed versions deprecated in M38.

name: webkitdropzone global attribute

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
The dropzone global attribute was introduced by the HTML5 drag and drop specification as a declarative method for specifying an HTML element's willingness to be the target of a drag-and-drop operation, the content types that can be dropped onto the element, and the drag-and-drop operation (copy/move/link).

No browser has implemented the unprefixed version. Blink and WebKit implement a prefixed form of the attribute, webkitdropzone. We would like to remove the prefixed attribute.

name: window.alert() will not activate parent page

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: If a document in a background tab calls window.alert() then the call to alert() will return immediately; the dialog will be shown to the user when they switch to the tab. A UI indicator will be set so the user is aware of the pending alert dialog. This removes the ability to use window.alert() to bring a tab to the front against the user’s will.

name: window.confirm() will not activate parent page

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: If a document in a background tab calls window.confirm() then the call to confirm() will return immediately with false, and no dialog will be shown to the user. If the tab is active, then the call will show a dialog. Specifically, this removes the ability to use window.confirm() to bring a tab to the front against the user’s will.

name: 'SameParty' cookie attribute

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Allows sites to indicate which cookies are allowed to be set or sent in contexts where all ancestor frames belong to the same First-Party Set.

view.notes: Second most starred Animation bug.

name: Animation Worklet

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Animation Worklet is a Houdini primitive that provides extensibility point for Web Animations and enables rich high-performance scripted animations which can (potentially) run off main rendering thread. 

It allows you to write rich imperative animations that run at the device's native frame rate for jank-free smoothness, make your animations more resilient to main thread jank. Future enhancement will enable such animations to also respond to user input (such as touch and scroll).

view.notes: No official position, concerns raised in PATCG
Engagement in previous origin trial

name: Attribution Reporting API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This API measures ad conversions (e.g. purchases) and attributes them to ad interactions without using cross-site persistent identifiers like third-party cookies. 


The API allows measurement through both event-level reports sent directly from the browser, and aggregatable reports which can be processed through a trusted service to create summary reports of attribution data.


An earlier version of this API was in Origin Trial from Chrome 86 through Chrome 97 which only supported click-through

name: Auto Picture-in-Picture

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Video in installed Progressive Web Apps (PWAs) will enter and exit picture-in-picture automatically when a document's visibility changes.

Web apps for video meetings will benefit by allowing picture-in-picture when users switch back and forth between web apps and other applications or tabs. This is currently not possible because a user gesture is required to enter picture-in-picture.

name: Back/forward cache NotRestoredReason API

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: NotRestoredReason API will report the list of reasons why a page is not served from BFcache in a frame tree structure, via PerformanceNavigationTiming API.

name: Budget API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This specification describes an API that can be used to retrieve the amount of budget an origin has available for resource consuming background operations, as well as the cost associated with doing such an operation.

name: CacheStorage Code Cache Hint

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
This experiment will allow participating sites to provide hints to cache_storage that full code cache should not be generated in a service worker install event.  The hint will be communicated as a header on the Response being stored.

This is a change to an unspecified optimization in chrome.  Full code cache generation during the install event was added in M64.  It is only observable indirectly through changes in timing and disk quota usage.

view.notes: Explicitly marked as positive as of 2022-10-18.

Jan-Ivar Bruaroey from Mozilla, and Youenn Fablet from Apple, have both collaborated with us closely in shaping the PRs of this API. They have then approved merging the PRs into w3c/mediacapture-screen-share. This is implicit support, so I'd consider it POSITIVE even though, as of the time of this writing, the official request for position has not yet been answered.
Support from Web developers inside+outside of Google.

name: Conditional Focus

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Extend the getDisplayMedia() API by adding a CaptureController object which can be passed in as a parameter. This object exposes a setFocusBehavior() method. By calling this method, an app can control whether the captured tab/window is focused when capture starts, or whether the capturing page should retain focus.

view.notes: https://github.com/WICG/contact-api/issues/20

name: Contacts API Addresses/Icons

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Extends the Contacts API (https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/6511327140904960) to support requesting addresses/icons as well.

view.notes: No signals on the new format

name: Dark mode support for web apps

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Add a field to the web app manifest which allows apps to specify a different theme color and background color for dark mode.

view.notes: W3C WebPerf: https://w3c.github.io/web-performance/meetings/2022/2022-03-31/index.html

name: Declarative PendingBeacon API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
A JavaScript API to allow website authors to specify one or more beacons that should be sent by the browser when a page is being unloaded.

The API improves beaconing when back/forward-cache is used, and it is more reliable than navigator.sendBeacon() or fetch() with keepalive.

view.notes: no official position, but have some concerns
In addition to the linked comment, we have some signals from partners that this would be valuable, and are checking to see if they are OK making that public

name: Document picture-in-picture

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Document PiP adds a new API to open an always-on-top window that can be populated with arbitrary HTMLElements.

This is an expansion upon the existing HTMLVideoElement API that only allows for an HTMLVideoElement to be put into a PiP window. This allows web developers to provide a better PiP experience to users.

name: Feature Policy violation reporting

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Enable reporting of feature policy violations through the Reporting API.

view.notes: We have been actively working with Firefox to standardize this API. In general we are aligned on the feature itself. e.g. auto re-authentication can provide streamlined UX without reducing privacy. Meanwhile, there are some open questions about what API is more suitable to achieve this goal. e.g. Firefox proposed to reuse the “mediation mode” in Credential Management API which is a promising direction as well. We will keep evaluating all the proposals and reach an alignment before shipping.
No signal for “auto re-authn” yet. Positive for the general FedCM API.

name: FedCM: Auto re-authentication API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This API provides streamlined re-authentication UX for users who have created a federated account on the Relying Party (RP) .

If an RP specifies `autoReauthn: true` in the FedCM API, for users who have granted permission to create a federated account in the browser client, they don't need to re confirm during the sign-in flow.

view.notes: Mozilla started to implement FedCM.

This API is being developed within the FedID CG with attendance of identity providers, browser vendors and standards experts.

https://github.com/fedidcg

name: Federated Credentials Management (was WebID)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The Federated Credential Management API allows users to bring their federated identity to login to websites in a manner compatible with improvements to browser privacy.

name: Federated Learning of Cohorts

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
The FLoC API would enable ad-targeting based on the user’s general browsing interest, without the websites knowing their exact browsing history. In today's web, people’s interests are typically inferred based on observing what sites or pages they visit, which relies on tracking techniques like third-party cookies. User privacy could be better protected if this can be accomplished without needing to collect a particular individual's exact browsing history.

OT targeted to start end of March.

name: Fenced frames

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Fenced frames are frames isolated from their embedding page. More details in the explainer here: https://github.com/WICG/fenced-frame/tree/master/explainer

The OT for fenced frames is part of the joint Privacy Sandbox OT, which follows the timeline here: https://privacysandbox.com/intl/en_us/open-web/

name: First "Locally-Executed Decision over Groups" Experiment (FLEDGE)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Provides a privacy advancing API to facilitate interest group based advertising.  FLEDGE shifts the interest data and the final ad decision browser-side instead of server-side, offering many advantages: strong privacy guarantees, as well as time limits on group membership, transparency into how the advertiser interest groups are built and used, and granular or global controls over this type of ad targeting.

name: Foreign Fetch

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Foreign Fetch is a proposal to enable third party Service Workers.

name: Increased max nesting level for setTimeout(0)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Increase the nesting threshold before which setTimeout(..., <4ms) start being clamped, from 5 to 15.

setTimeout(..., 0) is commonly used to break down long Javascript tasks and let other internal tasks run, which prevents the browser from hanging. setTimeouts and setIntervals with an interval < 4ms are not clamped as aggressively as they were before. This improves short horizon performance, but websites abusing the API will still eventually have their set setTimeouts clamped

name: Media Source Extensions for WebCodecs

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Extends the Media Source Extensions API (MSE) to enable buffering containerless WebCodecs encoded media chunks with MSE for low-latency buffering and seekable playback.

view.notes: Initial positive opinions on the issue, and continued engagement on the design, but not yet an official position

The initial public proposal, as well as the issue tracker and Twitter, has had great engagement and enthusiasm from developers.

Origin trial feedback was also encouraging.

In addition, we have several conversations going on with frameworks, libraries, and larger websites to ensure that we're solving the problems they see with today's history API. So far reactions have been either positive, or requesting that we add additional functionality (most notably https://github.com/WICG/app-history/issues/32).

name: Navigation API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The window.navigation API provides the ability to intercept and initiate navigations, as well as introspect an application's history entries. This provides a more useful alternative to window.history and window.location, specifically aimed at the needs of single-page web applications.

(Note: this API was formerly known as the app history API.)

name: Network State Partitioning

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Partition network state by the network partition key (which consists of top frame site and possibly frame site), to protect against cross-site tracking through the use of side channels.  "Network State" here includes connections (H1, H2, H3, websocket), the DNS cache, ALPN/H2 support data, TLS/H3 resumption information, Reporting/NEL configuration and uploads, and Expect-CT information.

Explainer: https://github.com/MattMenke2/Explainer---Partition-Network-State/blob/main/README.md

view.notes: Google Search is interested in experimenting with the header, specifically for the customizing server behavior use case.

name: No-Vary-Search support in navigation prefetch cache

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Enables prefetch to match even if URL query parameters change. The No-Vary-Search HTTP response header declares that some or all parts of a URL's query can be ignored for cache matching purposes. It can declare that the order of query parameter keys should not cause cache misses, that specific query parameters should not cause cache misses or that only certain known query parameters should cause cache misses. It could apply to multiple caches, but this entry refers to support for prefetch cache.

name: PerformanceResourceTiming.deliveryType

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Expose information about how a resource was delivered. For example, resources which were delivered from the cache (currently exposed through transferSize) and navigations which were prefetched by the previous page are useful to identify.

view.notes:
FF objects to this similar to sync-xhr and document-domain providing a way to cause cross-origin interference with script. Explainer addresses this (https://github.com/fergald/docs/blob/master/explainers/permissions-policy-unload.md#concerns-about-giving-embedders-control-over-the-nonexecution-of-iframe-code)

At a recent TPAC meeting with Mozilla people present, no negative feedback was received.

Request for formal position is here https://github.com/mozilla/standards-positions/issues/691

TAG review is here but has no feedback on the API itself.

https://github.com/w3ctag/design-reviews/issues/738

Private discussions with devs are positive.

Sites that have made efforts to remove all unload handlers want to use this to prevent accidental returns. Also some providers of 3rd-party iframes which have content outside of their control (e.g. ad network) want to guarantee themselves to be unload-free.

https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-permissions-policy/issues/444#issuecomment-1130401722

Also positive feedback about using this to deny unload as a source of security problems.

https://github.com/w3c/webappsec-permissions-policy/issues/444#issuecomment-1222973324

name: Permissions-Policy: unload

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
This feature allows pages to disable the running of unload event handlers. The goal is to :
- allow sites that have removed all unload handlers to ensure they do not accidentally add new ones
- allow sites to remove unload handlers when updating the code is infeasible

Unload event handlers are problematic for various reasons and prevent use of BFCache on Desktop (see https://web.dev/bfcache/#never-use-the-unload-event).

name: Portable Native Client (PNaCl)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Run C/C++ code compiled to bitcode on any web page. The code runs inside the Native Client sandbox and has access to the same capabilities as JavaScript via the Pepper APIs.

name: Privacy Sandbox Ads APIs

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A collection of APIs to facilitate advertising: FLEDGE, Topics, Fenced Frames and Attribution Reporting.

name: Private Aggregation API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A generic mechanism for measuring aggregate, cross-site data in a privacy preserving manner. The potentially identifying cross-site data is encapsulated into "aggregatable reports". To prevent leakage, this data is encrypted, ensuring it can only be processed by the aggregation service. During processing, this service will add noise and impose limits on how many queries can be performed.

view.notes: Positive signals on Twitter and HN

name: Reduce User Agent string information

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
We want to reduce the amount of information the User Agent string exposes in HTTP requests as well as in navigator.userAgent, navigator.appVersion, and navigator.platform.

The browser's brand and significant version, its desktop/mobile distinction and the platform it is running on will continue to be sent.

view.notes: This work saw strong support from Web developers inside of Google (Meet, Docs, Slides).

name: Region Capture

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: We introduce a performant and robust API for cropping a self-capture video track. (Recall that applications may *already* video-capture the tab in which the application is run using getDisplayMedia(). Using our new Region Capture, such an application may now *crop* that track and remove some content from it; typically before sharing it remotely.)

view.notes: Tentatively positive, but no formal position yet.

In our recent survey, most of websites are able to migrate if our new permission prompt can be landed as a way for them to relax mixed content checks.
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1z5ZdCslNCnSVR7TNlUTHjSvunMFmT_9G9NOx8-O78-I/edit?resourcekey=0-DITlG8tDuFDWHiBUHnlSoQ#gid=309953809
------------
Some websites, broadly falling in the category of controller webapps for IoT devices, find this change incompatible with their use cases. While many use cases can be solved with specific workarounds, some still require further engagement.

name: Restrict "private network requests" for subresources from public websites to secure contexts.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Requires that private network requests for subresources from public websites may only be initiated from a secure context. Examples include internet to intranet requests and internet to loopback requests. 

This is a first step towards fully implementing Private Network Access: https://wicg.github.io/private-network-access/

name: ServiceWorkerBypassFetchHandlerForMainResources
summary:
ServiceWorkerBypassFetchHandlerForMainResource (ServiceWorker fetch fast-path), is a change to the service worker implementation designed to let the browser bypass fetch handlers when appropriate.

With this feature, the request for the main resource will immediately happen without waiting for the ServiceWorker bootstrap and will also bypass the fetch handlers. The ServiceWorker is started at the same time as the request happens, but won’t intercept the request/response in the fetch handler. As a result, the browser can mitigate the bootstrap cost and the fetch handler execution.

name: Shared Array Buffers, Atomics and Futex APIs

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Adds the JavaScript type SharedArrayBuffer gated behind COOP/COEP. 
The concept of a SharedArrayBuffer is that a message to a worker, is posted but instead of copying the content of the array just a reference to it is shared.

The Atomic API provides atomic loads and stores and Read/Modify/Write accesses to SharedArrayBuffers.

The Atomic.wait provides the ability for a worker to wait for another worker to signal it, without having to spinlock.

name: Shared Storage API

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Allows for unpartitioned storage that may only be read in a secure environment with carefully constructed output gates. This API is intended to support many of the use cases of third-party cookies without permitting cross-site user tracking.

name: Skip Ad in Picture-in-Picture window

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Show a “Skip Ad” button in Picture-in-Picture window that notifies websites when user a interacts with it.

name: Speculation rules: delivery via Speculation-Rules header

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Currently developers can only specify speculation rules using inline script tags.  The proposed feature provides an alternative through the "Speculation-Rules" header. Its value must be a URL to a text resource with "application/speculationrules+json" MIME type. The resource's rules will be added to the document's rule set.

name: Speculation rules: document-sourced rules

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: An extension to speculation rules syntax that lets the browser obtain URLs for speculation from link elements in a page. They may include criteria which restrict which of these links can be used.

name: Topics API

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
The intent of the Topics API is to provide callers (including third-party ad-tech or advertising providers on the page that run script) with coarse-grained advertising topics that the page visitor might currently be interested in. These topics will supplement the contextual signals from the current page and can be combined to help find an appropriate advertisement for the visitor.

Explainer: https://github.com/jkarlin/topics

view.notes: Contact with sites using this API has been strongly in favor of keeping the functionality.

name: Web app launch handler

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

view.notes: Development is also ongoing, see: https://hg.mozilla.org/mozilla-central/file/tip/dom/webgpu
Standard position issue: https://github.com/WebKit/standards-positions/issues/107
Significant interest and positive feedback from the many early adopters (Babylon.js, Earth, TF.js, sokol-gfx, and many many others).

name: WebGPU

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The WebGPU API is the successor to the WebGL and WebGL 2 graphics APIs for the Web. It provides modern features such as “GPU compute” as well as lower overhead access to GPU hardware and better, more predictable performance. WebGPU is being developed by the “GPU for the Web” W3C community group.

name: WebRTC audio jitter buffer RTX handling

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Enables functionality in the audio jitter buffer in WebRTC to adapt the delay to retransmitted packets.

name: WebRTC relative packet arrival delay statistic

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add new non-standard audio receiver metric to the WebRTC getStats() API called relativePacketArrivalDelay. The metric estimates the delay of incoming packets relative to the first packet received.

name: WebXR Plane Detection API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The feature allows WebXR applications to retrieve data about planes (flat surfaces) present in the user’s environment. This enables AR applications to create a more immersive experiences through the obtained information.

name: [WebRTC] Unship deprecated "track" and "stream" stats from getStats()
summary: RTCPeerConnection.getStats() will no longer return stats objects where type == "track" or "stream". Unshipped in M112, with a Deprecation Trial to extend the availability of these metrics to M115.

name: aria-touchpassthrough

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Screen readers with touch screen support typically include a "touch exploration" mode where you can tap or slowly drag around the screen and listen to feedback on what you're touching, before it activates.

Setting aria-touchpassthrough on an HTML element indicates to a screen reader that touch events targeted at this element should be passed through directly, instead.

view.notes:
No signals on the standards-position ticket.

Annevk has been active on the standards discussions.
Positive at TPAC 2019 [1].

No signals on the standards-position ticket.

Positive at TPAC 2019 [1].
[1] 
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1q090ovJ4gd8wSfVtvuoZLMZ51YkiFDsEZ0Jiqi41Iys/edit#heading=h.85gziabhajhg

https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1438#issuecomment-1150755587
https://github.com/whatwg/fetch/issues/1438#issuecomment-1167984830

name: fetch() upload streaming

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Fetch upload streaming lets web developers make a fetch with a ReadableStream body. Fetch provides a generic definition of Request and Response objects (and other things involved with network requests).

view.notes: See discussion in thread.

name: Blocking insecure downloads from secure (HTTPS) contexts

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Chrome intends to block insecurely-delivered downloads initiated from secure contexts ("mixed content downloads"). Chrome will begin warning on, then blocking, progressively more mixed content downloads until all such downloads are silently blocked.

name: Heavy Ad Intervention

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Chrome will unload ad iframes that use an egregious amount of CPU or network bandwidth.

An ad will be subject to unload if it has not received a user gesture and:
  * Used the main thread for more than 60 seconds total
  * Used the main thread for more than 15 seconds in any 30 second window (50% utilization over 30 seconds)
  * Used more than 4 megabytes of network bandwidth to load resources

name: Intervention: Passive Touch Event Listeners During Fling

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Passive Event Listeners is a way to improve the scroll performance by unblocking scrolling on touch and wheel event listeners, so that scrolling happens immediately while the events are processed by javascript. alexclarke@ proposed that we should treat all the touchstart and first touchmove event listeners as passive while there’s an active fling animation.

name: Intervention: Rewrite slow pages for Lite Mode (Data Saver) users

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: On web pages that are expected to load slowly, Chrome may modify loading behavior to provide a faster page load to Lite Mode (Data Saver) users. This behavior modification can take many forms including but not limited to: blocking specific resources, loading partial resources, loading a previously saved version of the page, using Google servers to rewrite pages, etc.

name: Intervention: Scroll Anchoring

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Scroll anchoring adjusts the scroll position to prevent visible jumps (or "reflows") when content changes above the viewport.

Scroll anchoring introduces CSS "overflow-anchor" as an opt-out for developers.

name: Intervention: Stop loading of non-critical resources on slow pages for data saver users

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: On webpages that are expected to load slowly, stop loading of non-critical resources. This includes (but is not limited to) JavaScript and CSS resources that do not contribute significantly to the visual appearance. This would be limited to only the data saver users. Users are shown a Lite Mode UI in the omnibox. Users can load default behavior by tapping “Show original” in the omnibox UI. An intervention report is sent when this optimization occurs.

name: Intervention: Throttle expensive background timers

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
As an intervention we want to limit how much CPU a background page is allowed to use and to throttle timer queues when this limit is violated.

Current target is that background page CPU load level should be under 1%.

name: Intervention: Throttle rendering pipeline based on viewport visibility

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: As an intervention, stop running Blink's rendering pipeline (including requestAnimationFrame callbacks) for content which isn't visible in the viewport. This helps to avoid doing unnecessary work for animations which aren't going to be seen by the user.

name: Intervention: Throttle timers in out-of-view frames

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
As an intervention we want to limit the rate at which timers in out-of-view, cross-origin frames are able to fire.

Until very recently it wasn't possible for script authors to easily determine whether their content was visible to the user or not. A common pattern therefore is to use a continuous setTimeout() loop for driving animations without considering visibility, which can be very costly for performance.

name: Intervention: WebFonts use adaptive timeouts to take fallback fonts

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Originally, Blink use fallback fonts if the font loading isn't finished in 3 seconds. But this timeout value wasn't defined in any spec.

Blink changes this timeout adaptively to improve performance on slow connections.

If font-display feature is enabled, this change happens only if 'auto' is specified to follow the font-display spec. Otherwise, it happens always.

The definition of slow connection would be changed in the field trial.

name: JavaScript dialogs exit HTML5 fullscreen

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: If a page shows a JavaScript dialog while it is in fullscreen (the HTML5 kind), it is exited from fullscreen.

name: Require user gesture for beforeunload dialogs

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: The beforeunload dialog will only be shown if the frame attempting to display it has received a user gesture or user interaction (or if any embedded frame has received such a gesture). (There will be no change to the dispatch of the beforeunload event, just a change to whether the dialog is shown.)

name: Stop showing ads on websites that are not compliant with the Better Ads Standards.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Stop showing ads (including ads owned or served by Google) on sites that do not comply with the betterads.org/standards

Feature Intro:
https://blog.chromium.org/2017/06/improving-advertising-on-web.html

How Chrome's ad filter works
https://blog.chromium.org/2018/02/how-chromes-ad-filtering-works.html

Filtering began on sites globally in July 2019.
https://blog.chromium.org/2019/01/building-better-world-wide-web.html

Ad Experience Report Info
https://support.google.com/webtools/answer/7159932

name: Temporarily stop permission requests after 3 dismissals

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Temporarily stop an origin from requesting a permission following the third dismissal of a permission prompt. The stop will be lifted after some amount of time has passed (initially 1 week), after which the origin may request the permission again. A further dismissal will apply the temporary stop again.

For web developers who are testing features, the block can also be removed by changing the permission's setting in the lock icon's page info dialog, or by clearing your browsing data.

name: Treat Document Level Touch Event Listeners as Passive

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
AddEventListenerOptions defaults passive to false. With this change touchstart and touchmove listeners added to the document will default to passive:true (so that calls to preventDefault will be ignored)..

If the value is explicitly provided in the AddEventListenerOptions it will continue having the value specified by the page.

This is behind a flag starting in Chrome 54, and enabled by default in Chrome 56. See https://developers.google.com/web/updates/2017/01/scrolling-intervention

name: window.focus() exits HTML5 fullscreen

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: If a page in fullscreen mode opens a popup and calls window.focus(), that page will exit full screen. This will not occur if the popup receives focus some other way.

name: window.prompt() will not activate parent page

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: If a document in a background tab calls window.prompt() then the call to prompt() will return immediately, and no dialog will be shown to the user for that call to prompt(). If the tab is foremost (if it is the active tab in the front window), then the call will show a dialog. Specifically, this removes the ability to use window.prompt() to bring a tab to the front against the user’s will.

name: Exclude implicit tracks from grid-template-rows/columns resolved values

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Implicit tracks will be excluded from the resolved values of the grid-template-rows and grid-template-columns. Previously, all tracks were included, whether implicit or explicit.

view.notes: "worth prototyping"
Various sites have expressed support, mostly as part of the WebAppsSec discussions, for the things which are enabled by origin policy.

name: Origin Policy

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Origin Policy provides a mechanism for defining configuration options with origin-wide impact.

This status item covers Origin Policy infrastructure and support for Content Security Policy and Feature Policy policy items.

view.notes: The current spec is the outcome of the discussion with Mozilla.
81 comments on the spec discussion including multiple positive feedback from developers.

name: Web Audio Render Capacity API

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Web Audio Render Capacity API is a way preemptively determine audio thread overload.

Generally, the Web Audio renderer’s performance is affected by the machine speed and the computational load of an audio graph. However, Web Audio API does not expose a way to monitor the computational load, and it leaves developers no options to detect glitches that are the essential part of UX in audio applications. This API provides developers with a “glitch indicator”.

name: <script src="x|y"> fallback syntax

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Layered APIs (LAPIs) are a new standards effort for shipping high-level features, exposed to the web as JavaScript modules. Their specifications are required to be layered on top of existing lower-level platform features, and never use any "magic" that is inaccessible to JS developers.

This feature covers the infrastructure for importing LAPIs, via std:x|y module specifiers in <script type=module> and JS import statements.

name: <virtual-scroller>

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
The <virtual-scroller> element provides a scrolling "viewport" onto some content and allows extremely large numbers of elements to exist, while maintaining high performance by only paying the cost for those that are currently visible.

This will be implemented as a built-in module.

name: @font-face descriptor advance-override

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: The advance-override descriptor scales all character advances of the font face by the given percentage. It can be used to match text width between two fonts, and hence reduce layout shift caused by web font loading.

name: Accept-CH-Lifetime support for requesting client hints

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Client Hints enables user agents to provide device-specific preferences in the HTTP request headers. Accept-CH-Lifetime adds a client hint that allow origins to persist their opt-in policy for a specified period so they can receive client hints on main frame requests. Additionally, on the first page load, this feature provides hints for all subresources of the page.

This is expected to be enabled by default in Chrome 67.

name: Accessible Object Model (AOM)

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: This effort aims to create a JavaScript API to allow developers to modify (and eventually explore) the accessibility tree for an HTML page.

name: Add purpose member to the Web App Manifest

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Chrome will use the purpose member in the Web App Manifest to determine which icon to use in the status bar for notifications for "Improved Add to Homescreen" web apps (described https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YJwrBbze_Ec)

This is already possible for Android M+ using notification badges described in https://www.chromestatus.com/features/5630897160192000
Using the "purpose" member will enable doing this for pre-M Android

name: Automatic focus by Selection interface functions

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Chromium has a behavior that functions of Selection interface automatically set focus on an element contains the new selection. This behavior isn't defined by the standard, and it is not interoperable.

name: BasicCardResponse.expiry{Month,Year} should be 2 digits

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
The expiryMonth field contains a two-digit string for the expiry month of the card in the range 01 to 12.

The expiryYear field contains a two-digit string for the expiry year of the card in the range 00 to 99.

name: Bidi caret affinity

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Blink has confusing behaviors and bugs with bidirectional text selection and editing. The main cause is bidi adjustment, which maps between logical and visual positions at bidi boundaries.

To fix these bugs, bidi affinity is replacing bidi adjustment. Users won't see many differences, but developers will. See the comments box for specifics.

name: COEP reflection API

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Add the crossOriginEmbedderPolicy property to Window and Worker, which reflects the environment's cross-origin-embedder-policy's value.

The possibles values are: 'unsafe-none', 'credentialless', and 'require-corp'.

name: CORS-RFC1918: CORS restrictions on internet-to-intranet connections.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: We'll begin requiring servers on a user's machine (127.0.0.1) or intranet (as defined by RFC1918) to explicitly opt-in to connections originating from the public internet. Hopefully, this will mitigate the risks associated with unintentional exposure of devices and servers on a client’s internal network to the web at large.

name: CSS Regions

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Magazine-like content flow into specified regions.

view.notes: Mozilla proposed this resolution. They did not want to style containment at all.
WebKit has not shipped CSS containment. For some reason it's marked as passing all tests in wpt.fyi.

name: CSS containment: Remove style from strict and content

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The 'strict' and 'content' keywords for the 'contain' property used to include 'style'. Per CSSWG resolution and spec change this is no longer the case.

name: CSS font-display for @font-feature-values

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Support is added for a default font-display descriptor in the @font-features-values rule.

This feature provides a way for authors to set a default font-display for @font-face rules where none is provided. This could be useful for controlling font-display for third party font-faces like Google fonts.

name: CanMakePaymentEvent.respondWithMinimalUI

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add a mechanism for a payment handler to enroll in a golden path, low friction payment experience. In addition to the existing CanMakePaymentEvent.respondWith() event, this feature will add a new method CanMakePaymentEvent.respondWithMinimalUI() that the payment handler could choose to use.

name: Canvas rendering from workers

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Render a Canvas object (2D or WebGL) from a web worker.

name: Canvas2D text decoration

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Add a textDecoration attribute to canvas 2D contexts, behavior similar to existing "font" attribute: It's a DOMString, parsed the same way as corresponding CSS property (text-decoration).

name: Cap page-scoped referrer policies

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
We’re considering mitigating indiscriminate sharing of information about navigations’ sources by introducing a cap on the granularity of widely-scoped referrer policies.
Page-scoped referrer policies (those set via <meta name=”referrer”> or the Referrer-Policy header on documents) with values of "unsafe-url", "origin-when-cross-origin", and "no-referrer-when-downgrade" will be treated as if they were instead "strict-origin-when-cross-origin".

name: Clear browsing context name on cross site navigation or history traversal

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Clear browsing context name on cross site navigation or history traversal

name: Comprehensions (dropped from ES6)

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Concise syntax for transforming collections.

name: Custom filters (shaders)

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Apply OpenGL shaders to arbitrary DOM elements.

name: Dart VM

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Dart is a new web programming language with libraries, a virtual machine, and tools.  It's designed to help developers build fast, structured modern web apps.  Dart compiles to JavaScript to run across the entire modern web. The VM is a Chrome feature to optimize Dart's performance.

name: Debug API

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Expose some Debug API to user's JavaScript code.

name: Declarative Link Capturing for PWAs

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
=== Obsoleted by web app launch handler: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5722383233056768 ===

Web App Manifest members to control what happens when the user navigates to a page within scope of an installed web app.
- Automatically open a new PWA window when the user clicks a link to their app.
- Have a "single window mode" like mobile apps.

Was in origin trial from M91-M97:
https://developer.chrome.com/origintrials/#/view_trial/4285175

name: Default Style for Custom Elements

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This feature will allow a default style for custom elements at the point of their registrations.

This will add a UA-stylesheet like capability to custom elements without the need to attach a shadow root and have a style sheet in each of its instances.

view.notes: Safari expressed approval for removing the feature.

name: Deprecate and remove support for 'volume' property.

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Remove support for the 'volume' property in getUserMedia() constraints and MediaStreamTrack APIs. The property and related constraint were removed from the Media Stream Capture specifications (see https://github.com/w3c/mediacapture-main/issues/585).

name: Disallow spaces and other bad characters in hostnames

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Chrome currently allows some technically invalid characters in hostnames, which it percent-escapes. These host names will now be marked as invalid.

view.notes: This is mostly a bug fix, so it doesn't look we need to ask for specific web developer signals.

name: Do not invert selection background color when it matches text color

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Right now selection background color is inverted when it matches the text color in Chromium.
So if you have a rule like this "::selection { color: cyan; background: cyan; }" the background gets inverted and red color is used.
This is an old behavior inherited from WebKit (https://trac.webkit.org/changeset/52548/webkit) but Safari doesn't do this anymore (and Firefox has never done this).
The proposal is to stop inverting the background color for ::selection.

name: Dynamic Delegation of Autoplay Capability

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A tentative API to experiment with dynamic overrides for "autoplay" feature policy.

name: FIDO U2F JavaScript API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Web platform API to provide U2F support.

name: Feature Policy: Legacy Image Format

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
Allows developers to selectively enable and disable the use of images with legacy image formats through the Feature-Policy HTTP header or the <iframe> 'allow' attribute.

This provides more control over images using legacy formats, on a per-origin basis. Use this policy to improve image loading performance.

The identifier for the feature in policies is 'legacy-image-formats'. By default, 'legacy-image-formats' is allowed in all frames.

name: Feature Policy: Sandbox Features

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This change allows developers to selectively enable and disable sandbox features in any frame, including top-level documents, through the feature policy HTTP header or the <iframe> "allow" attribute.

These features are included:
"forms"
"modals"
"orientation-lock"
"plugins"
"pointer-lock"
"popups"
"presentation"
"scripts"
"top-navigation"

view.notes: 'Shipped' as in Firefox also removed frames() in favour of steps()

name: Frames timing functions

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Quoting the spec: "A frames timing function is a type of timing function that divides the input time into a specified number of intervals of equal length, each of which is associated with an output progress value of increasing value. ... This makes it suitable, for example, for using in animation loops where the animation should display the first and last frame of the animation for an equal amount of time as each other frame during each loop." See the spec link for examples.

name: Freeze task queues in background

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
[We no longer intend to ship this feature, see https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/blink-dev/c/sotCDcI-E7Y/m/3x8clb3PEgAJ]

All freezable task queues of a page that has been backgrounded for five minutes will be frozen simultaneously, if the page is “freezable”.

A page is “freezable” if it hasn’t opted-out of freezing via origin trial and if it hasn’t been opted-out by heuristics (playing audio, holding locks, capturing user media...).

name: GamePad API touch and motion extensions

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Additions to the gamepad API to enable devices with touch-sensitive controls and devices that are capable of tracking position, orientation, and/or motion. VR controllers will benefit from the new attributes, as will more traditional gamepads with these types of inputs.

name: Geofencing API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The Geofencing API is an extension of the Geolocation API allowing web applications to setup geographic boundaries around specific locations and then receive notifications when the user enters or leaves those areas.

name: Ignore clicks on recently moved cross-origin iframes

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Ignore clicks on cross-origin iframes when the location of the click is not within the iframe’s bounds for all draws that occurred within the last 200 ms.

name: IndexedDB IDBObjectStore.putAll()

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Adds a new method to the IndexedDB API's IDBObjectStore interface that will let developers bulk-insert many records into an IndexedDB object store.

name: IndexedDB Observers

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: IndexedDB observers allow a developer to listen to changes to their database, including changes from other browsing contexts.

name: Intent to deprecate: PseudoBeforeAfterForInputElement

docs: Refer to bug for current status.
Some public discussion on not going through with he deprecation warning is here: https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!topic/blink-dev/_czoEgSJMQs

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Intent to deprecateusage of pseudo elements ::before and ::after For Input Elements as it goes against spec.

name: Intrinsic size attribute

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This attribute allows developers to specify the intrinsic size of a media element (,

name: KV storage

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
KV storage provides a simple, asynchronous key/value store with a modern API. Additionally, it allows easy creation of isolated storage areas beyond the default one.

KV storage is layered on top of IndexedDB, storing its data in a specific database, so the developer can fall back to using IndexedDB directly when necessary.

name: Lazy layout

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Support a system for doing lazy layout based on what elements are visible in the viewport.

name: Link rel=serviceworker

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
Add support for LINK rel=serviceworker as an element and header to allow the installation of Service Worker declarative in a document or via a header.

Update (2018-03-26): This was removed from the specification and is no longer being pursued.

name: Media Queries: shape feature

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The shape feature describes the general shape of the targeted display area of the output device.

name: Merchant Validation

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Merchant validation is the process by which a payment handler validates the identity of a merchant against some value (usually some cryptographic challenge response). Validated merchants are allowed to interface with a payment handler. The PaymentRequest's onmerchantvalidation event is invoked when the user agent requests merchant validation on behalf of a selected payment handler.

name: Microdata

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary: Microdata is used to nest semantics within existing content on web pages.

name: Microtransaction payment handlers

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: A low friction experience for users that are enrolled with payment handlers that support microtransactions.

name: More restrictive hasEnrolledInstrument() for autofill instruments

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Improves the authorization of transactions by requiring unexpired cards and a billing address. This improves the quality of autofill data and increasing the chances that PaymentRequest.hasEnrolledInstrument() returns true.

name: More restrictive show() for autofill instruments

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Improves the authorization of transactions by requiring unexpired cards and a billing address. This improves the quality of autofill data and increasing the chances that PaymentRequest.show() returns a valid response.

name: More strict checking of valid URL hostname characters

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
These characters, if encountered in the host name portion of a URL, are accepted and percent-escaped.

  <space> , } { * ‘ ( & ) > < | " = $ ! @ ` #

These characters are disallowed by the spec and are generally unsupported, although in rare cases they can work. Chrome will remove this category of accepted-but-escaped characters in URL host names and treat such URLs as invalid.

name: Navigation Transitions

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allows web authors to both improve the perceived loading speed as well as provide visual polish by allowing two pages to coordinate on a transition animation (regardless of their origin).

name: Navigation to Bundled Exchanges

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary:
Bundled HTTP Exchanges represent a collection of HTTP exchanges. An HTTP exchange is a pair of HTTP request/response. It can include signatures with the semantics of Signed HTTP Exchanges, or not.

This feature allows Chrome to navigate into Bundled HTTP Exchanges, i.e. browser can navigate into a page whose entire resources (including main and sub resources) are bundled in a Bundled Exchange. It is expected to enable easy sharing and offline browsing of a web site.

name: NavigatorContentUtils.IsProtocolHandlerRegistered API

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Web developers are able to register or unregister custom schemes, but there is no way to verify that the custom schemes are well registered. NavigatorContentUtils.IsProtocolHandlerRegistered is a way to check whether a custom scheme is registered.

name: Offset-based Touch Adjustment

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
No longer pursuing.
New plan: https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/4895751150764032
---
Touch Adjustment is the feature where UA attempts to select the best target underneath the finger.

Offset-based Touch Adjustment will run the selecting algorithm only on TouchStart, and apply the same offset (between adjusted coordinates and original coordinates) to all following TouchMove/End as well as gesture/click events. Will run hittest for each event with adjusted coordinates.

name: OverconstrainedErrorEvent

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary:
This event is used to signal if, during operation, the settings of the track changed in such a way that it is not possible to satisfy the constraints for this track any longer. If so, the offending track is muted and the event is raised so that the application can address the problem appropriately.

This is useful for getting more consistent behavior across browsers and allow for better control for the application.

name: Pause HTML parser while loading stylesheets in <head>

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Pause the HTML parser waiting for stylesheets to load instead of blocking rendering for FOUC (Flash of Unstyled Content) avoidance.

name: PauseFrame

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Allows for pausing of frames (via JavaScript API as well as browser intervention). When a frame is paused, it doesn't run script and it doesn't load resources. It waits patiently to be resumed.

name: Per-method quota for PaymentRequest.hasEnrolledInstrument()

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary: Separate hasEnrolledInstrument() calls should be used to query whether a user has a Google Pay wallet and whether they have cards in the autofill database. This ability is supported without letting sites iterate payment instruments within these locations. Previously Chrome would reject PaymentRequest.hasEnrolledInstrument() with NotAllowedError if a website queried different payment methods or different payment method specific parameters within a span of 30 minutes.

name: Permission automation for registerProtocolHandler

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
Provides Automated testing support for the registerProtocolHandler() method, so that we can avoid the user prompt dialog for granting permission for the protocol handler registration.

We would need to define a new 'PermissionName' that we can use as part of the 'PermissionDescriptor' argument for the SetPermission command provided by the WebDriver API.

name: Progressive Web Apps as URL Handlers

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Enables web applications to register as https URL handlers using their web app manifest.

name: Raw Clipboard Access

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Raw Clipboard Access provides a low-level API to allow interoperability between web and native application clipboards, by implementing copying and pasting of data with any arbitrary Clipboard type, without encoding and decoding.

name: Remove currencySystem in PaymentRequest API

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: The `currencySystem` member was removed from PaymentRequest API spec. Removal at this time does not preclude it being added to a future version of the API. Current implementations of Payment Request API allow the use of well-formed currency codes that are not part of the official ISO4217 registry. If the provided code is a currency that the browser knows how to display, then an implementation will generally display the appropriate currency symbol in the user interface.

name: Remove non-primary button click event

maturity.text: Final published standard: Recommendation, Living Standard, Candidate Recommendation, or similar final form

summary:
According to the spec https://w3c.github.io/uievents/#event-type-click the non-primary buttons should not fire mouse click events. This is the change to make Chrome inline with the spec in that regards.

This change is no longer pursued. But it will be done as part of another change with auxclick:
https://www.chromestatus.com/feature/5663174342737920

name: SIMD.js

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary:
SIMD.js exposes hardware SIMD instructions to Javascript applications in a platform-independent way. Add three SIMD vector types: float32x4, float64x2, and int32x4, and corresponding Typed Array views.

SIMD.js can speed up applications that process lots of data that is naturally organized as 2, 3, or 4 element vectors. SIMD is also useful when compiling native code to Javascript for static compilation by the Javascript engine.

name: Safelist mapping, version control, and digital object identifier URL schemes for "registerProtocolHandler"

docs: Also: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/2546 and https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/3080 for mapping and DOI respectively.

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: Extend list of URL schemes that can be overridden via registerProtocolHandler() to include bzr, bzr+ftp, bzr+lp, bzr+http, bzr+https, bzr+sftp, bzr+ssh, cvs, cvs+ext, cvs+pserver, cvs+ssh, darcs+http, darcs+https, darcs+ssh, git, git+http, git+https, git+ssh, hg, hg+http, hg+https, hg+ssh, hg+static-http, lp, svn, svn+http, svn+https, svn+ssh, map, gmap, bingmap, location, doi

name: Screen Capture

maturity.text: Specification being incubated in a Community Group

summary: This extension enables the acquisition of a user's display, or part thereof, in the form of a MediaStream. This enables a number of applications, including screen sharing using WebRTC.

name: Scroll Customization (Houdini)

maturity.text: Specification currently under development in a Working Group

summary: Add applyScroll and distributeScroll methods to Element, enabling customization of how scroll deltas are applied and distributed. This will enable extending or replacing native scrolling behaviors.

name: Scroll to CSS selector

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
To enable users to easily navigate to specific content in a web page, a CSS selector may be used to indicate part of the document.

Indicated part of the document: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/browsing-the-web.html#the-indicated-part-of-the-document

name: Searchable Invisible DOM

maturity.text: Proposal in a personal repository, no adoption from community

summary:
Note: 
The Searchable Invisible DOM proposal has merged with Display Locking (https://github.com/WICG/display-locking), and we are no longer pursuing Searchable Invisible DOM.

Old proposal: create some new way of exposing DOM to the browser, that is still searchable, but is invisible. That is all things that work only if the content is in the DOM (like Find-in-page, fragment URL navigation, a11y, tabindex) should work, but we don’t need to pay for the cost of styling, layouting, etc.

view.notes: Facebook is interested in using this API in multiple web apps if the experiment is successful

name: Service Worker subresource filter

maturity.text: Unknown standards status - check spec link for status

summary: Allows control over what requests are intercepted by Service Worker fetch events.
